questions.text: Identify the lateral semicircular canal?
questions.solution:
Lateral semi-circular canal in the given picture is marked as ‘C’.

Structures Marked in the Diagram:
A : Incus
B : Posterior semicircular canal
C : Lateral semicircular canal
D : Superior semicircular canal

The vestibule is positioned anteriorly to the three semicircular canals: anterior (superior), posterior, and lateral (horizontal). Each one is squeezed from side to side until it is about two-thirds of a circle in size.
Except for where they bear an ampulla, which is about twice as wide as the canal, they are unequal in length but similar in diameter along their lengths.
 

Reference : https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Gross-anatomy-the-structures-exposed-following-a-classical-mastoidectomy-LSCC-lateral_fig4_373287463

questions.text: A man arrives with aphasia. He is unable to name items, and his repetition is poor. However, comprehension, fluency, and understanding of written language are unchanged. He's presumably suffering from?
questions.solution:
• Conduction aphasia results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus.
  • The connection between the Wernicke's (language comprehension) and Broca's (Language production) areas is lost.
  • The hallmark of conduction aphasia is the inability to repeat words. Comprehension and the expression of language are intact but patients cannot transfer the understood word to Broca's area to be expressed.
  • Conduction aphasia results in meaningful fluent speech and relatively good comprehension but very poor repetition.



Reference : HARRISON'S Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition - pg.196 table 30.1

questions.text: Pick the option that is not true about malignant otitis externa.
questions.solution:
Chief complaint in cases of Malignant Otitis Externa is usually the presence of severe, continuous, and deep-seated otalgia and not Hearing Loss. Hence, option (3) is not a true statement.
The clinical features of a patient of Malignant Otitis Externa are : Severe, unrelenting, deep-seated otalgia ,Temporal headaches, Purulent otorrhea, Possibly dysphagia, hoarseness, and/or facial nerve dysfunction.
Granulation tissues are seen on superior wall of the external auditory canal: This is true. Granulation tissue, often seen in the external auditory canal, is a characteristic finding in malignant otitis externa

questions.text: A patient went to the OPD complaining of  rotatory vertigo after waking up in the morning caused  by head movement. What is your medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of the patient who complains of rotatory vertigo in the morning caused by change in head position is suggestive of Benign Paroxysmal positional vertigo.
 
This condition is caused by displacement of calcium crystals most commonly into the posterior semicircular canal which leads to vertigo on change in head position as the calcium crystals get distributed and stimulate the posterior semicircular canal.

questions.solution:
Congenital Stapes Anomalies with Normal Eardrum:
Incus and stapes anomalies > isolated stapes anomalies > anomalies in all 3 ossicles.
Among stapes anomalies: Stapes footplate fixation only > Mobile stapes footplate with other anomalies> Stapes footplate fixation with other anomalies > Isolated stapes defect.

questions.text: Which of the following hearing impairments benefits the most from the use of audio neurotherapy?
questions.solution:
The vestibular system of the inner ear is only involved in Meniere's illness. Thus, a Neurotherapy i.e. a direct nerve stimulation will only be effective in Meniere's illness. A shift in the labyrinth's fluid volume is what causes this inner ear condition.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is advised for newborn hearing screening?
questions.solution:
National Deafness Programme recommends OAE as a screening method for hearing assessment
It is not the investigation of choice which is ABR/BERA
 
Usually, a two-step screening process is used where those infants which fail in OAE are subjected to BERA/ABR


Types of OAE
 

Types of OAE Definition Remarks
Spontaneous OAE Sounds emitted spontaneously ie without a stimulus Seen in 20-75% neonates and their absence doesn't dignify abnormality
Transient Evoked OAE Sounds emitted to a stimulus of very small duration Used for Screening.
Distortion product OAE Sounds emitted to 2 simultaneous tones but of different frequencies

Used for early detection of cochlear damage (especially for noise-induced damage/ototoxicity)

questions.text: A patient arrives at a clinic to have their hearing checked. With the Weber test lateralized to the right ear, Rinne's test reveals air conduction to be stronger than bone conduction on both sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Weber's test lateralization to the right indicates either right conductive deafness or left sensorineural deafness. Now in conductive deafness, BC is better than AC in Rinnie's test, hence the patient probably has sensorineural deafness involving the left ear, as per the findings of Rinnie and Weber tests. Schwabach's test should be carried out in this situation to determine the absolute bone conduction and to validate these results.     

           

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 24

questions.text: What is the most commonly affected by noise-induced hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Noise induced hearing loss mostly affects the outer hair cells.

It is of two types:

  • Temporary threshold shift : Hearing status is recovered after a while
  • Permanent threshold shift : Permanent loss of hearing, due to increase in threshold.


Chronic noise exposure damages the metabolism and the ultrastructure of the organ of Corti, initially resulting in the loss of outer hair cells and ultimately leading to neuronal degeneration.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 37

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by the wave V in the BERA?
questions.solution:
Wave 5th (V) in bera is due to Lateral laminiscus. Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is a non-invasive examination which is used to determine the integrity of a patient's auditory pathway up to the brain. Electrodes are placed over various parts of the head and auditory stimuli (clicks/tone bursts) are given to the patient. These responses to the stimulus are picked up by the electrodes and charted by the computer to measure the patient's hearing sensitivity between 1000 and 4000 Hz. Seven waves are produced in the first 10 milliseconds, with the first, third, and fifth waves being the most important for analysis. Parameters studied are the absolute latency of each wave, the interwave latency (between the first and third, the third and fifth, and the first and fifth) and the amplitude of each wave.Origin of each wave: I distal part of VIII nerve II proximal part of VIII nerve (towards brainstem) III cochlear nucleus IV sup olivary complex V lateral lemniscus VI inferior colliculus VII Medial geniculate body

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 29

questions.text: Which of the following is not removed during a stapedotomy?
questions.solution:
In stapedotomy, all the given options except lenticular process of incus are removed. Stapes surgery is a surgical procedure used to treat hearing loss. The steps involved include making an incision in the external ear canal, elevation of the skin, exposing the stapes area, dislocation of the incudostapedial joint, cutting the stapedial tendon, removal of the stapes superstructure, Incudostapedial joint is dislocated. When the stapes is free, the stapedial tendon is cut and stapes superstructure including anterior and posterior crus are removed. This leaves the whole incus and the stapes footplate behind and making or removing a hole in the stapes footplate for the insertion of a piston. The aim of the procedure is to improve hearing levels by restoring the movement of sound from the outer ear to the inner ear.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 97

questions.text: Which of the following cochlear implant components is implanted during the surgery?
questions.solution:
Receiver/ stimulator parts of cochlear implant is implanted during surgery. Cochlear implants are surgically placed electronic devices which can provide improved hearing for those with severe to profound hearing loss. They consist of an external speech processor and transmitter, along with an internal receiver/stimulator and electrode array, implanted surgically.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 139

questions.text: The external auditory canal of a 75-year-old diabetic patient has granulation tissue, which is causing acute ear pain and face nerve involvement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Necrotizing otitis externa (NOE), also known as malignant otitis externa, is a severe invasive infection of the external auditory canal (EAC) which can spread rapidly to involve the surrounding soft tissue, adjacent neck spaces and skull base. 

Pathology

Predisposing conditions for necrotizing otitis externa include diabetes and immunosuppression (i.e. diabetes or patients receiving chemo- and/or radiation therapy), and is usually seen in elderly patients. Pain can be out of proportion for typical otitis externa.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the pathogen in 98% of cases. The route by which the infection spreads is variable. It can spread anteroinferiorly to involve the suprahyoid neck spaces (parotid space and masticator space). Alternatively, the infection can also erode the cartilaginous-bone of the external auditory canal resulting in a direct intracranial spread with resultant serious intracranial complications. 

Serious complications include:

  • skull base osteomyelitis (
  • subdural empyema
  • cerebral abscess
  • meningitis
  • facial nerve palsy
  • temporomandibular joint involvement
  • dural venous sinus thrombophlebitis.
IOC- Tc 99m scan 
Prognostic IOC- Gallium 67 scan
DOC- Ciprofloxacin 

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 55

questions.text: What is implanted during the cochlear implant surgery?
questions.solution:
The internal components of a cochlear implant are the receiver/stimulator (implanted under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the Scala tympani of the cochlea).

Microphone, Speech-processor, and Transmitter are components of the cochlear implant that remain outside the body.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 139

questions.text: Tympanometry was ordered for a 35-year-old pregnant woman who complained of hearing loss that has gotten worse during pregnancy. Which type of graph will be seen?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has otosclerosis, which is more common in females and worsens during pregnancy. On tympanometry As type of curve would be observed which shows decreased compliance of tympanic membrane and normal middle ear pressure. The decreased compliance is due to fixation of footplate of stapes seen in otosclerosis. Ad curce sugests ossicular discontinuity.B curve is a flat curve and suggests fluid in ear. C curve represents retracted TM.

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male presents with persistent ear discharge with fever and headache. He complained of pain out of proportion. On examination, granulations and tenderness are observed on the floor of the external auditory canal along with facial nerve palsy. He is not responding to antibiotics. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Malignant otitis externa (MOE) is a severe infection of the external auditory canal and surrounding structures. It is caused by organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus spp, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus aureus, and Aspergillus species. Symptoms include severe ear pain, otorrhea (ear drainage), redness and tender area around the ear, hearing loss, and general malaise. Chronic cases can lead to facial nerve palsy, cranial nerve deficits, as well as osteomyelitis (bone infection). Diagnosis is usually made with imaging tests, such as computed tomography scan and magnetic resonance imaging, IOC- Tc 99m scan and Prognostic IOC- Gallium 67 scan. Treatment usually consists of antibiotics and topical medications, but surgery may be necessary in severe cases.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 55

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with persistent fullness of left ear for 3 months and hearing loss. On examination, there is fluid behind the tympanic membrane. Impedance audiometry shows a type B audiogram. The next step for the management of the patient would be:
questions.solution:
Endoscopic examination is recommended for any nasopharyngeal pathology in a 58-year-old male who presents with persistent fullness of the left ear for 3 months and hearing loss with fluid behind the tympanic membrane, and impedance audiometry showing a type B audiogram.It is to be done before myringotomy, because Nasopharyngeal CA(which is common in this age group) needs to be ruled out before anything else. It can identify any underlying causes of the fluid build-up and hearing loss, such as a tumor, inflammatory process or obstruction of the eustachian tube. The use of endoscopy allows for visual inspection of the nasopharynx and tympanic membranes, as well as the opportunity to take biopsies of any abnormalities in order to make a more accurate diagnosis.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 27

questions.text: Bone anchored hearing aid (BAHA) can be used in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Baha is a type of bone anchored hearing system. Some of the main features and indications of Baha include:

1.When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
- Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment
-Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment
- Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid

2..Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated

3.Single sided hearing loss

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 137

questions.solution:
William F. House considered as 'Father of Neuro-otology' because of his pioneering development approaches for the removal of acoustic tumors and the management of patients with disabling vertigo.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with left ear discharge and mild ear pain for the past 7 years. There is no history of deafness. On examination, the tympanic membrane is intact and discharge is seen coming from the posterior superior wall. The left ear canal and tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chronic otitis externa is a chronic infection/inflammation of the skin lining the external ear canal, often caused by repeated local irritation, insertion of foreign objects, or rare chronic infections such as syphilis, tuberculosis, and leprosy. Symptoms include itching, mild pain, asteatosis, thickening of the skin lining of the external canal, and sometimes mucopurulent otorrhea. Treatment includes use of acetic acid ear drops to reduce the pH of the skin and, in extreme cases, surgery such as a canaloplasty to widen the external canal and grafting of the removed skin.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 54

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Bell's palsy except:
questions.solution:
Immediate nerve decompression is not required in Bell's palsy, initially steroids are given and recovery occurs in 85-90% cases. Nerve decompression relieves pressure on the nerve fibers and improves the microcirculation of nerve, done in non-responding cases. Rest all statements are true.

questions.text: A girl for chronic ear discharge, pain on ocular movements and vertigo underwent mastoidectomy. There was no relief post-operatively and continuous purulent ear discharge was seen. Patient also had sensorineural hearing loss. The most probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Petrsoitis is a rare complication of suppurative otitis media affecting both acute and chronic forms. Acute petrositis is marked by extension of mastoiditis into the petrous apex while chronic petrositis usually occurs due to mucosal or cholesteatomatous CSOM and does not require pneumatization of the petrous apex. Classic features include otorrhea with retroorbital pain and lateral rectus palsy (Gradenigo syndrome). Antibiotics and surgical drainage of the petrous apex are recommended for management.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 88

questions.text:
What is the encircled structure in the middle-ear cavity called ?


1`. Fossa incudis
2. Sinus tympani
3. Facial recess
4. Pyramidal fossa
questions.solution:
The sinus tympani (ST) is a critical anatomic region of the temporal bone. It lies medial to the facial nerve, between the ponticulus and the subiculum. This is the most common and constant depression present in the retrotympanic area. It is the most inaccessible site in the middle ear and mastoid. Cholesteatoma which has extended upto it is very difficult to eradicate.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 7

questions.text: Where will the placement location for the auditory brainstem implant be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Recess of 4th ventricle

Auditory brainstem implant is placed in the Recess of the 4th Ventricle. It replaces the cochlear nerve and is usually indicated in congenital absence of  cochlear nerve or in post-op excision of cochlear nerve in acoustic neuroma.
Cochlear implant is placed in scala tympani via round window.

questions.solution:
Vestibular schwannoma most frequently starts at the Inferior vestibular nerve in the Internal acoustic meatus. It is the most common type of Cerebello Pontine angle tumor affecting the elderly or young with NF2 ( bilateral) or NF1 (unilateral).

questions.text: Otoacoustic emissions begins at the:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: outer hair cells 

Otoacoustic emissions(OAE) begin at Outer Hair cells (OHC). OHCs are more prone to noise-induced trauma and ototoxicity. Hence, OAE is used to detect early noise-induced hearing loss, to differentiate between cochlear (OAE are present) and retro cochlear (OAE are absent) and to screen hearing in neonates as an objective test.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 29

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the widening of the  cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure in which a small portion of the conchal cartilage, known as the meatus, is removed to widen the cavity. This procedure helps to ensure the healthy growth of epithelial tissue in the mastoid cavity and is commonly combined with radical and modified radical mastoidectomies in order to provide access for further inspection and cleaning. It can also be done as a standalone procedure to improve the appearance of sagging outer ears in older individuals.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 455

questions.text: Superior semicircular dehiscence presents with all except :
questions.solution:
The Tullio phenomenon is observed in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS), while sensorineural hearing loss is not seen. The vestibular activation brought on by sound or pressure is referred to as the Tullio phenomenon. Conductive Hearing Loss is seen in SCC dehisense. Patients report feeling dizzy as a result of pressure or noise. Some people might exhibit persistent imbalances. The patient adopts a noise avoidance strategy. Some people may also have hyperacusis or gaze-evoked tinnitus.

Reference : https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3578588/#:~:text=Results%20and%20Conclusions%20Symptoms%20of,Tullio%20phenomenon)%2C%20among%20others

questions.text: An individual who was in an accident suffered a fractured middle cranial fossa. Behind the mastoid, there was a bluish purple colour. What is the likely cause of your condition?
questions.solution:
Battle's sign is a bruise at the bottom of the skull, located behind the ear in the mastoid area. It is seen in temporal bone fractures and can indicate a serious injury or fracture. Other common findings of temporal bone fractures include blood in the external auditory canal (EAC), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) otorrhoea, hemotympanum (blood behind the eardrum), tympanic membrane perforation (TM pertoration), and facial nerve palsy on the affected side. These symptoms may range from mild to severe depending on the extent of the fracture. Battle's sign is a significant indicator of a fracture in the temporal bone and requires further medical assessment.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 507

questions.text: What does not characterise TB otitis media?
questions.solution:
Tubercular otitis media is an infection of the middle ear following pulmonary tuberculosis. Symptoms include painless ear discharge, multiple perforations, severe hearing loss, and in some cases facial paralysis. Diagnosis typically includes observation of pale granulations on examination. Common complications include mastoiditis, labyrinthitis, post-auricular fistula, and osteomyelitis.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 81

questions.text:
Which of the following describes a CSOM complication?
A. Griesinger's sign
B. Bezold’s sign
C. Delta sign
D. Histelbeger’s sign
E. Battle sign
questions.solution:
• Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis, an intracranial complication of CSOM, is characterised by Gresinger's and the Delta sign.
 
  • Subperiosteal abscess of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, an extratemporal consequence of CSOM, is Bezold's sign.
 
  • Hitzelbeger’s sign is seen in acoustic neuroma characterized by hypoanesthesia along posterior meatal wall due to involvement of seventh cranial nerve. 
 
  • A fracture of  temporal bone exhibits Battle's sign.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 86

questions.text:
Patient was operated for safe CSOM in right ear. He then presented with
complaints of vertigo, tinnitus & ear fullness. He experienced relief on
turning his head to the opposite side. Identify his condition.
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical history, patient develops tinnitus, vertigo and ear fullness which are signs of labyrinth (inner ear) pathology.

He developed his symptoms just after surgery for CSOM which imples that he could have had an inner ear injury during the surgery. Among the given options, perilymphatic fistula is most appropriate as it is common after middle ear surgeries like that of CSOM. Perilymphatic fistula is the formation of abnormal communication between the perilymph filled inner ear and outside the inner ear.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man who complained of bilateral hearing loss and sporadic episodes of dizziness was examined; his HPE is displayed below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
VESTIBULAR SCHWANNOMA HPE:

  • Unencapsulated but otherwise resembles schwannomas at other locations
  • Interlacing fascicles of cells with indistinct cytoplasmic borders, elongated and twisted nuclei
  • Biphasic with Antoni A (cellular) and B (hypocellular, myxoid) patterns and Verocay bodies (whorling or palisading of nuclei)
  • Hyalinization of vessels
  • Commonly have regressive ("ancient") changes (cellular pleomorphism with hyperchromasia, cystic degeneration, necrosis, calcification, hemorrhage)
  • May be highly cellular (cellular schwannoma)

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 125

questions.text: In a real-world instance, Epley's maneuvre was used to identify and treat vertigo that occurred for a brief period of time and was related to head posture. What is the diagnostic test for the aforementioned condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of vertigo lasting for a few seconds which is associated with position is suggestive of Benign Paroxysmal positional vertigo.
 
This condition is treated using Epley's manoeuvre and is diagnosed using the Dix Hallpike manoeuvre.
In the Dix Hallpike Manoeuvre, the examiner stands at the patient's head and 45 degrees to the right to make the body's sagittal plane align with the right posterior semicircular canal.
 
The patient's eyes are open and he is moved from the seated to the supine position with the right ear down. The patient's neck is then slightly extended so that the chin points slightly upward. If nystagmus is present, we note its latency, duration, and direction. If vertigo is present, note its latency and duration.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 44

questions.text: What is the star-marked structure and what does the angle depict?

questions.text: Gelle's test is conducted in:
questions.solution:
Gelle's Test evaluates the effect of modified air pressure on someone's hearing when the tympanic membrane and ossicles are pressed inwards by the Siegel's speculum.

Normally, in this situation, diminished hearing occurs due to a change in intralabytintbine pressure and immobility of the basilar membrane.

Gelle's test is conducted by using a vibrating fork on the mastoid while the ear canal is being pressurized with the Siegel's speculum. The test will be positive in people with normal hearing and those with sensorineural hearing loss, however, it will be negative in cases with fixed or disconnected ossicular chains.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 25

questions.text: What is the best surgery to relieve intractable vertigo in a Meniere's disease patient?
questions.solution:
Labyrinthectomy is the most intrusive and dramatic treatment for people affected by Meniere's disease who have unremitting vertigo. It involves completely destroying the vestibular and hearing functions. To be a suitable candidate for this type of surgery, the patient must have no remaining useful hearing ability and no success with more conservative treatments, including the gentamicin injection.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 115

questions.text: With cold water, a caloric test was performed on the right side. Eyes shifted to the other side. Which of the following describes how nystagmus should be interpreted correctly in this test?
questions.solution:
The caloric test is used to assess the functioning of the lateral semicircular canal, which is responsible for detecting movement of the head. As a result, this test can help identify peripheral vertigo. The nystagmus associated with this test is of the horizontal or torsional type, and will not be vertical. To conduct the caloric test, cold or hot water is instilled into the ear; the side of the nystagmus will depend on the temperature; with cold water, the nystagmus occurs on the opposite side of the ear being tested, and with hot water, it will occur on the same side (can be remembered by the mnemonic "COWS: Cold opposite, warm same").

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 45

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of cochlea.

questions.text: What is the initial mechanism of action of intra-tympanic gentamicin given for the treatment of Meniere's disease:
questions.solution:
Gentamicin, when administered via trans-tympanic injection, primarily affects vestibular type I and type II hair cells while sparing the cochlear inner and outer hair cells. This makes it a vestibulotoxic drug. 

Gentamicin targets the transport channels (Na+ K+ ATPase) on vestibular hair cells, allowing it to accumulate in these cells and lead to their death, thereby alleviating vertigo symptoms without compromising hearing, as it does not impact inner and outer hair cells or the stria vascularis. It's noteworthy that vestibular type I hair cells are particularly susceptible to damage from Gentamicin.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 115

questions.text: A 6 years old child was brought to the ENT OPD with the complaints of hearing loss, earache and delayed speech. Otoscopic examination findings are shown below in the image. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss, earache and delayed speech with otoscopic findings of a dull tympanic membrane with fluid levels and air bubbles goes in favor of otitis media with effusion. 
 

Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), also known as glue ear, is the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs of infection. It is common in children and may lead to hearing loss and speech delays if untreated.

Cause:

  • Eustachian tube dysfunction (most common).
  • Upper respiratory infections, allergies, and environmental factors like passive smoking.
  • Anatomical issues such as cleft palate.
Symptoms: 
  • Hearing loss (most common).
  • Fullness or pressure in the ear.
  • Rare balance problems.

Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam (otoscopy shows fluid behind the eardrum).
  • Tympanometry to assess middle ear pressure.
  • Audiometry to detect hearing loss.

Management: 
  • Observation: Many cases resolve on their own within 3 months.
  • Surgical: Tympanostomy tube placement for persistent cases or significant hearing loss.
  • Medical: Decongestants and antihistamines may help, but antibiotics are generally not recommended.

Complications: 
  • Persistent hearing loss affecting language development.
  • Recurrent ear infections or cholesteatoma (rare).
Prevention: 
  • Minimize exposure to smoke and allergens, practice good hygiene, and encourage breastfeeding.

OME typically resolves on its own, but persistent cases require monitoring and possible treatment to avoid complications like hearing loss.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 58, 67, 69-71.

questions.text: A patient with damage of basilar membrane presented with high frequency hearing loss. Most likely site of lesion:
questions.solution:
The affected structure in high frequency hearing loss is basal turn of cochlea. 

Among the given options, the structure present in close proximity to basal turn of cochlea is oval window. 

The basilar membrane in the cochlea is tonotopically organized:

  • The base of the basilar membrane (near the oval window) is stiff and narrow, making it sensitive to high-frequency sounds.
  • The apex of the basilar membrane (near the helicotrema) is wider and more flexible, making it sensitive to low-frequency sounds.

Damage to the basilar membrane near the oval window would impair the detection of high-frequency sounds, leading to high-frequency hearing loss.

Other options: 

  1. Stria vascularis: (Option 1)

    • Produces endolymph and maintains the ionic composition necessary for normal cochlear function. Damage here causes global cochlear dysfunction, not frequency-specific loss.

  2. Helicotrema: (Option 2)

    • Located at the apex of the cochlea, it is involved in low-frequency sound detection. Damage here would cause low-frequency hearing loss, not high-frequency.

  3. Modiolus: (Option 4)

    • The central bony core of the cochlea housing the spiral ganglion neurons. Damage here typically causes neural or sensorineural hearing loss rather than being frequency-specific.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 10, 11, 17.

questions.text:
Match the following 
a. Type II Tympanoplasty 1. Graft on round window
b. Type III Tympanoplasty 2. Fenestration operation
c. Type IV Tympanoplasty 3. Graft in Incus
d. Type V Tympanoplasty 4. Graft on Head of stapes
questions.solution:
• Type II Tympanoplasty → 3. Graft in Incus:

    • The ossicular chain is partially disrupted, so the graft is placed on the incus to restore continuity.

  • Type III Tympanoplasty → 4. Graft on Head of Stapes:

    • In this procedure, the graft is placed directly on the head of the stapes when the malleus and incus are absent.

  • Type IV Tympanoplasty → 1. Graft on Round Window:

    • The ossicular chain is absent, and the graft covers the round window to protect the inner ear while allowing sound conduction.

  • Type V Tympanoplasty → 2. Fenestration operation:

    • Used in cases of fixed stapes footplate or severe ossicular damage; a new opening (fenestration) is created to improve hearing.


TYPES OF TYMPANOPLASTY:

questions.text:
A patient presented with complaints of hearing loss. Rinne’s test using 256 and 512 Hz tuning forks is negative while the test is positive with 1024 Hz tuning fork. What is the air-bone gap in this patient?

1. 0 – 15 dB

2. 15-30 dB

3. 30-45 dB

4. More than 45 dB
questions.solution:
A Rinne's test positive test indicates that air conduction is better than bone conduction, while a negative test indicates the opposite.

  • In this case, the Rinne's test is negative with 256 and 512 Hz tuning forks, but positive with 1024 Hz tuning fork.
  • This indicates that the patient has a conductive hearing loss, as the sound is not being transmitted efficiently through the outer or middle ear to the inner ear.
  • In this case, as the Rinne's test is negative with the lower frequency tuning forks, it suggests that there is a problem with the transmission of sound waves through the outer or middle ear.
  • The positive Rinne's test with the 1024 Hz tuning fork indicates that the inner ear is functioning normally. Therefore, the correct answer is option 3: 30-45 dB, as this range indicates a moderate conductive hearing loss.
Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page. No- 26.

questions.text: The audiogram of a patient who presented with a gradually progressive hearing loss, tinnitus and vertigo is given below. Which among the following would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The audiogram presented is indicative of early-stage Ménière's disease, showing an upsloping curve that suggests initial impairment of lower frequencies.

In contrast, conditions such as presbycusis, ototoxicity, and noise-induced hearing loss typically exhibit downsloping audiograms, indicating that higher frequencies are affected first.

Key points to note in pure tone audiometry (PTA) audiograms include:

• Abnormal air conduction (AC) with normal bone conduction (BC) and the presence of an air-bone gap indicates conductive hearing loss.
• A downsloping audiogram shows higher frequency loss, characteristic of presbycusis, ototoxicity, and noise-induced hearing loss.
• An upsloping audiogram indicates that lower frequencies are affected first, as seen in early Ménière's disease.
• A U-shaped, trough-shaped, or cookie-bite audiogram reflects midfrequency hearing loss, commonly found in congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis.
• An acoustic dip represents a notable decrease in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz.
A Carhart notch is identified by a dip at 2000 Hz in the BC curve.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with pain in his right ear. He is diagnosed with right sided otitis media after investigations. He also adds that he recurrently gets these ear infections. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 50-year-old male presents with recurrent otitis media, which is often unilateral in adults. This raises suspicion for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, particularly because:

  • Recurrent otitis media in adults is uncommon and usually secondary to Eustachian tube obstruction.

  • NPC often arises in the nasopharynx, near the Eustachian tube opening, causing middle ear effusion and recurrent infections.

  • Other symptoms may include nasal obstruction, epistaxis, neck mass (cervical lymphadenopathy), or cranial nerve palsies.

Other options:

  • Pyogenic granuloma: Benign vascular lesion; presents as a rapidly growing, bleeding mass, usually in skin or mucosa.

  • Glomus tumor (paraganglioma): Highly vascular tumor, often presents with pulsatile tinnitus and hearing loss, not recurrent otitis media.

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Occurs in adolescent males, not a 50-year-old.

Hence, in a middle-aged adult with recurrent unilateral otitis media, the most likely underlying cause is nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea. Investigations revealed that his HbA1C is 10%. The likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Malignant otitis externa (MOE) is a life-threatening infection of the external auditory canal that can extend to the skull base, commonly seen in elderly diabetic patients with poorly controlled blood sugar (HbA1C elevated).

Clinical features:

  • Severe ear pain (otalgia), often out of proportion to physical findings

  • Otorrhoea (purulent discharge)

  • Possible cranial nerve involvement in advanced cases

Pathophysiology:

  • Most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa

  • High glucose and impaired immunity in diabetics predispose to aggressive soft tissue infection

Differentiation:

  • Eczematous otitis externa → mild itching, erythema, scaling, usually not severe pain

  • Serous otitis externa → fluid accumulation behind tympanic membrane, painless

  • Otomycosis → fungal infection, itchy, flaky discharge, less severe pain

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding.
questions.solution:
Battle sign is bruising over the mastoid process, typically appearing 24–48 hours after a basilar skull fracture, especially temporal bone fractures.

Key points:

  • Indicates basilar skull fracture, often posterior cranial fossa involvement.

  • May be associated with hemotympanum, CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea, and cranial nerve injuries.

  • Other signs for comparison:

    • Griesinger sign: Posterior auricular tenderness or erythema indicating mastoid involvement, often in mastoiditis.

    • Bezold abscess: Deep neck abscess due to mastoiditis complication.

    • Mastoiditis: Inflammation of mastoid air cells, usually post-otitis media.

Clinical relevance:

  • Battle sign is a critical external marker of basilar skull fracture, alerting clinicians to monitor for neurological complications and CSF leak.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presented with pain and hearing loss after trauma to his right ear. Otoscopy reveals the presence of blood clots along with irregular perforations in the tympanic membrane. What is the next step in management in this case?
questions.solution:
In traumatic tympanic membrane perforation with blood clots and mild hearing loss, the initial management is usually conservative, as most perforations heal spontaneously within a few weeks.

Key points:

  • Keep the ear dry: Prevents infection and allows natural healing.

  • Systemic analgesics: For pain control.

  • Observation: Follow-up to monitor healing; tympanoplasty considered if perforation does not heal after 3–6 months.

  • Avoid: Topical antibiotics with aminoglycosides if the tympanic membrane is perforated, due to risk of ototoxicity.

  • Audiometry and aspiration are not immediately required unless there is persistent hearing loss or complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with hearing loss underwent an audiogram, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pure tone audiogram depicted is indicative of otosclerosis. Key features observed include:

Air-Bone Gap: Present, indicating a difference between air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC).
BC > AC: Suggestive of conductive hearing loss.
Key Points:
Otosclerosis is the only condition among the options that primarily causes conductive hearing loss.
Carhart's Notch: This characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz is specifically associated with otosclerosis and typically resolves after successful stapes surgery.
PTA in Sensorineural Hearing Loss:
There is no air-bone gap present.
Both BC and AC fall within the hearing loss range (greater than 25 dB).

choices.text: Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in otitis media with effusion
Otoscopy shows loss of light reflex of tympanic membrane
Characterized by the accumulation of purulent serous effusion in the middle ear cleft
usually occurs following an episode of common cold

questions.text: All of the following are features of otitis media with effusion EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
• Serous otitis media also known as secretory otitis media, mucoid otitis media, or glue ear is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent, serous effusion in the middle ear.
  • Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in otitis media with effusion
  • Hearing test- Rinne negative suggestive of Conductive hearing loss
  • Impediance audiometry - Flat curve
  • Otoscopy shows loss of light reflex of tympanic membrane
  • Treatment is aimed at removal of fluid and preventing recurrence


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No 75-77.

questions.text: Which of the following is not recommended in an 8y old child with Bilateral SNHL?
questions.solution:
• Adenoidectomy with Grommet insertion is not recommended in Bilateral SNHL.
  • It is recommended in Serous Otitis Media.
  • The best treatment in above situation would be cochlear implants and hearing aids.
Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page No 37,105 142-147.

questions.text: <strong>Arrange the following structures in the hearing pathway from the receptors to the cortex
questions.solution:
The auditory pathway progresses as follows: spiral ganglion, cochlear nucleus, olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, and auditory cortex.

The spiral ganglion, located in Rosenthal's canal, houses bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells converge to create the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve, which terminates in the cochlear nuclei.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 17 .

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:
A. Cochlear nucleus
B. Spiral ganglion
C. Superior olivary nucleus
D. Inferior colliculus
E. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans-
Ans-The auditory pathway follows this sequence: spiral ganglion (2) - cochlear nucleus (1) - superior olivary nucleus (3) - inferior colliculus (4) - medial geniculate body (5).

The spiral ganglion houses bipolar cells, with their dendrites providing the afferent input from the inner and outer hair cells of the organ of Corti. These cells' axons form the cochlear division of cranial nerve VIII, which terminates in the cochlear nuclei.

To remember the auditory pathway, use the mnemonic ECOLIMA:

Eighth nerve

Cochlear nuclei

Olivary complex

Lateral lemniscus

Inferior colliculus

Medial geniculate body

Auditory cortex

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 16,17 .

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with the issue of hearing speech sounds but struggling to comprehend the words. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) results are fairly normal, but the Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results are inconsistent with PTA, showing absent middle latency and cortical responses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a clinical scenario involving a child who has difficulty understanding words and presents with abnormal Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) while having normal Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA), auditory neuropathy should be considered.

Auditory neuropathy, or auditory dyssynchrony, is a disorder that impairs the neural processing of sound. The condition is characterized by:

Injury to the synaptic junction between the inner hair cells of the cochlea and the dendrites of the spiral ganglion neurons

Direct damage to the dendrites of the spiral ganglion neurons

Direct injury to the spiral ganglion neurons

Direct axonal damage to the auditory nerve


It is crucial to suspect auditory neuropathy in children who exhibit severe speech and language delays disproportionate to their perceived level of hearing loss.

For a diagnosis of auditory neuropathy in newborns, the following criteria must be met:

Absent or severely abnormal Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) test results at maximal stimulus levels (100 dBnHL)

Normal outer hair cell function as determined by Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs)

Absent or elevated stapedial reflex thresholds


In adults with mildly to moderately abnormal pure tone thresholds and disproportionate speech discrimination scores, further evaluation is necessary. Audiograms may show normal or slightly elevated pure tone thresholds.

Management typically involves conventional hearing aids. If a child does not show progress with hearing aids and has limited speech discrimination, cochlear implantation is considered the next option.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no43-44,103-106,135 .

choices.text: Fracture of the roof of the nose

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with CSF otorrhea?
questions.solution:
CSF otorrhoea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through the ear. It occurs when there is a breach in the dura mater and temporal bone, allowing CSF to escape through the external auditory canal. This typically arises from a fracture of the middle cranial fossa due to head trauma, particularly a temporal bone fracture.

An associated finding of the middle cranial fossa fracture is the Battle sign. It is a clinical sign, that refers to bruising over the mastoid process and is suggestive of an underlying injury to the base of skull.



On the contrary, CSF Rhinorrhea refers leakage of CSF via the nasal cavity, and it is often seen in Anterior Cranial fossa fractures, particularly of the cribriform plate. It may also be associated with clinical signs such as the raccoon eyes.

Other options:

Option A: Traumatic rupture of the tympanic membrane typically presents with sudden onset, severe ear pain, conductive hearing loss and blood-tinged ear discharge, however not CSF otorrhea.

Option B: Penetrating injury to the eye, is not anatomically related to the middle cranial fossa, and thus CSF Otorrhea to occur would be highly unlikely.

Option C: Fracture of roof of the nose, i.e. the cribriform plate typically presents with CSF rhinorrhea and not CSF Otorrhea.

Features of CSF Otorrhea
 

  • Clear, watery discharge → from the external auditory canal.

  • Worsens with straining → discharge increases with coughing, sneezing, or bending forward (↑ intracranial pressure).

  • Halo sign / Target sign → CSF forms a central blood spot with a clear outer ring on filter paper.

  • Glucose-positive fluid → unlike normal ear secretions, CSF contains glucose.

  • Beta-2 transferrin positive → highly specific marker for CSF (not present in blood or nasal/ear secretions).

  • Recurrent meningitis → chronic CSF leaks predispose to meningitis.

  • History of trauma or surgery → commonly follows basilar skull fracture, temporal bone fracture, or post-ear surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles in the external auditory meatus and over the tympanic membrane. In addition to that, he also has facial nerve palsy. What is the most likely diagnosis and which is the site that is affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described is indicative of Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which involves the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).

Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as herpes zoster oticus, is a late complication of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection. The varicella-zoster virus is a double-stranded DNA virus that causes inflammation in the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve.

Clinical features include ipsilateral facial paralysis, a vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna, along with intense ear pain. Additional symptoms can include anesthesia of the face, giddiness, and hearing impairment due to the involvement of the trigeminal nerve (V) and vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).

The syndrome is classically characterized by a triad of:
Ipsilateral facial paralysis
Otalgia (ear pain)
Vesicles in the auditory canal or on the auricle.
Treatment typically involves antiviral medications such as acyclovir or famciclovir, in combination with corticosteroids like prednisone to reduce inflammation and pain.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her mother with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss over the past 2-3 months, accompanied by vesicles on the superficial layer of the tympanic membrane, is indicative of myringitis bullosa.

Bullous myringitis (also known as myringitis bullosa hemorrhagica) is characterized by the presence of vesicles on the superficial layer of the tympanic membrane without involvement of the external or middle ear.
If the middle ear becomes involved, it would be classified as acute otitis media. This condition is typically caused by infections from the influenza virus or Mycoplasma pneumoniae. When a bulla ruptures, it can lead to bloody otorrhea, which is referred to as bullous hemorrhagic myringitis.

questions.text: What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.solution:
• The utricle and saccule are part of the vestibular apparatus (otolith organs).

  • They contain maculae with hair cells embedded in an otolithic membrane containing calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia).

  • Function → detect linear acceleration and head position relative to gravity (static equilibrium).

    • Utricle → detects horizontal linear acceleration.

    • Saccule → detects vertical linear acceleration.

Other options:

  • Angular acceleration: Detected by semicircular canals (crista ampullaris).

  • Hearing low-frequency / high-frequency sounds: Function of the cochlea, not utricle/saccule.

questions.text: A 35-year old woman presented to the clinic with the symptoms of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Further examination reveals conductive hearing loss with Rinne test negative. A reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario suggests the presence of a glomus tumor.

A glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm found in the middle ear, typically occurring in middle-aged females. It is composed of paraganglionic cells that originate from the neural crest and is characterized by its extreme vascularity.

There are two primary types of glomus tumors: glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum. The glomus jugulare tumor arises from the dome of the jugular bulb and can invade the hypotympanum, while the glomus tympanicum tumor originates from the promontory of the middle ear.

Clinical features of glomus tumors include:

Conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus, which are often the earliest symptoms.
An otoscopic examination may reveal a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane, described as a "rising sun" appearance, due to the tumor's location at the floor of the middle ear.
There may be paralysis of the 9th to 12th cranial nerves in advanced cases.
An audible bruit over the mastoid can be heard upon auscultation, which is present at all stages of the tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following is a screening test used for detecting hearing loss in a newborn?
questions.solution:
A newborn baby on the same day of delivery will undergo the Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) test as a screening test for hearing.
Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal.
The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible, or latest by 6 months of age.
In India, a two-stage screening protocol is followed according to which infants are screened first with otoacoustic emissions (OAE). Infants who fail the OAE are screened with auditory brainstem response (ABR) or Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA), which is also the definitive test. All babies kept in NICU must be screened by BERA test as per the protocol. Ref - PL Dhingra disease of ENT 8th edition page 32, 138

questions.text: Ostmann pad of fat is associated with which of the following structures?
questions.solution: The Ostmann fat pads are masses of fatty tissues located inferolateral to the cartilaginous eustachian tubes. It helps keep the tube closed, protecting it from the reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and also prevents the transmission of nasopharyngeal pressure to the middle ear. Ref- PL Dhingra 8th edition page 67

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Gradenigo syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Typical presentation of Gradenigo's Syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrositis (a complication of otitis media).
Gradenigo's syndrome is a triad that consists of:
• Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)
• Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
• Persistent ear discharge (otitis media). Ref -PL Dhingra disease of ENT 7th edition Page 87-88

questions.text: In the case of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, where is the anterior ethmoidal nerve most commonly compressed?
questions.solution:
The middle meatus is the most common site of compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve causing neuralgia.
Anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, also known as Sluder's neuralgia is caused when the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (which is itself a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, CN V1), is compressed. The most common site of compression is at the middle meatus, where the nerve may be impinged by anatomical variations, inflammation, or other pathologies affecting the paranasal sinuses.
The anterior ethmoidal nerve enters the nasal cavity by descending through the cribriform plate near the crista galli. Once in the nasal cavity, the nerve descends along the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It runs above the superior border of the middle meatus and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the anterior part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity
The patient typically presents with severe, sharp, and stabbing pain localized to the forehead and the root of the nose, often radiating to the periocular region. The pain is usually unilateral but can occasionally be bilateral.
Associated symptoms may include tenderness over the affected area and occasionally nasal congestion or discharge if there is concurrent sinusitis.
Ref: Online Resource •

Yadav, Ram & Chakraborty, Priyanko & Saini, Rajat & Kumar, Rajesh & Saroj, Sanjay & Yadav, Shishupal. (2022). Anterior Ethmoidal Nerve Syndrome - An Under-diagnosed Cause of Headache. Bengal Journal of Otolaryngology and Head Neck Surgery. 30. 35-40. 10.47210/bjohns.2022.v30i1.648.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for balance and equilibrium?
questions.solution:
The semicircular canals are three loop-shaped structures filled with endolymph fluid and lined with hair cells that detect angular acceleration in three planes (horizontal, vertical, and oblique).
When the head moves, the fluid inside these canals shifts, causing the hair cells to bend. This bending generates nerve impulses that are transmitted to the brain via the vestibular nerve, informing the brain about the direction and speed of head movement.
The vestibule, which includes the utricle and saccule, also contributes in a minor amount towards maintaining balance by detecting linear acceleration and the position of the head relative to gravity.
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition • Page no 10

questions.text: A 26 year old pregnant female presents with hearing loss. The following finding is seen on PTA. Identify the condition
questions.solution:
Pure tone audiometry showing a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Carhart's notch is seen in otosclerosis. Other findings include As type of tympanogram. Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It is seen in women between 20-30 years of age and is precipitated by pregnancy. Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis is the treatment of choice.
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition • Page no. 95 and 96

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
• The child presents with:

    • Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections

    • Poor growth, high-arched palate, impaired hearing

    • Tympanogram shows a Type B curve → flat curve, indicating middle ear effusion / otitis media with effusion (OME).

  • Most appropriate management in children with recurrent OME and hearing impairment:

    • Grommet (ventilation tube) insertion → relieves middle ear effusion and restores hearing

    • Adenoidectomy → indicated if there is recurrent URTI, nasal obstruction, or adenoidal hypertrophy, which often contributes to OME in children >4 years

Other options:

  • Grommet insertion alone: May be sufficient in some cases, but in the presence of adenoidal hypertrophy / recurrent URTI, adenoidectomy improves long-term outcomes.

  • Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Essentially the same as grommet insertion; adding adenoidectomy is preferred in this scenario.

  • Myringotomy alone: Temporary relief only; effusion may recur without grommet.


Reference
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery - 8th Edition - Page no: 29, 75-77

questions.text: A middle aged woman presents with complaints of hearing her own voice and breath sounds. On examination, the tympanic membrane was moving with respiration. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient hears her own voice (autophony) and breath sounds, which are classic features of Patulous Eustachian Tube (PET).

  • On examination, the tympanic membrane moves with respiration, another hallmark finding of PET.

  • Cause: Rapid weight loss leads to reduction of peritubal fat around the Eustachian tube → tube remains abnormally open → patient perceives their own voice and breathing loudly.

Other options:

  • Meningioma: Can cause hearing loss but not tympanic membrane movement with respiration.

  • Middle ear infections: Cause conductive hearing loss, not autophony due to PET.

  • Auditory hallucinations: CNS origin, not related to tympanic membrane or respiration.


Reference
PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition - Page no 65

questions.text: On performing caloric test, which kind of nystagmus would be observed on doing cold water irrigation?
questions.solution:
• The caloric test assesses the function of the vestibulo-ocular reflex by irrigating the external auditory canal with warm or cold water.

  • Cold water irrigation → causes endolymph in the horizontal semicircular canal to sink, mimicking head movement to the opposite side → results in slow deviation of the eyes to the same side, followed by fast corrective phase (nystagmus) to the opposite side.

  • Rule to remember: COWS → Cold Opposite, Warm Same (for the direction of nystagmus).

Other options:

  • 2. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side → Not seen in caloric test; it mainly produces horizontal nystagmus.

  • 3. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side → Incorrect, caloric test does not produce vertical nystagmus.

  • 4. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side → This happens with warm water irrigation, not cold.


Reference
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery - 8th Edition - Page no 49

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with ear wax and was subjected to syringing to remove the wax. She developed a syncopal episode while doing the procedure when the tip of the syringe touched the ear canal. Which of the nerves is responsible for this episode of syncope?
questions.solution:
The syncopal episode during ear syringing is most likely due to vagal stimulation caused by irritation of Arnold’s nerve, which is the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X).

Arnold’s Nerve Reflex (Ear–Cough Reflex or Ear–Syncope Reflex):

  • Arnold's nerve supplies the posterior and inferior part of the external auditory canal and the external ear.

  • Stimulation (e.g., syringing or foreign body) can cause:

    • Coughing (most common)

    • Bradycardia

    • Vasovagal syncope

      Other Options:

  • Auriculotemporal nerve: Branch of CN V3; supplies anterior part of external auditory canal; not associated with vagal reflex.

  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): Supplies the middle ear via Jacobson’s nerve, but does not cause vagal syncope on external canal stimulation.

  • Jacobson’s nerve: Tympanic branch of CN IX; innervates middle ear, not external canal.


Reference: Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat-PL dhingra page no 5

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Test Normal Hearing Conductive Hearing Loss Sensorineural Hearing Loss Principle
Rinne Test AC > BC (Rinne positive) BC > AC (Rinne negative) AC > BC (Rinne positive, but both reduced) Compares air vs bone conduction
Weber Test Sound heard equally in both ears Lateralizes to affected ear Lateralizes to normal ear Tests lateralization via bone conduction
Schwabach Test Patient and examiner hear sound equally (normal) Prolonged Schwabach (patient hears longer than examiner) Shortened Schwabach (patient hears shorter than examiner) Compares bone conduction with examiner
Gelle’s Test Tone becomes fainter or disappears with pressure No change in sound with pressure (abnormal) Sound becomes fainter (normal response) Tests ossicular chain compliance
 

This patient initially had:

  • Acute otitis media → possible complication → labyrinthine fistula

  • Complaints: Sudden unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo

  • Positive Rinne & fistula test at first

  • Now, further worsened hearing, fistula test turned negative

  • Question is about current expected Rinne test result

    Understanding the Tests:

    Rinne Test Interpretation (512 Hz tuning fork):

Rinne Result Meaning
Positive AC > BC → normal or sensorineural loss
Negative BC > AC → conductive hearing loss
False Negative Sensorineural loss incorrectly gives a negative Rinne test (because of sound being heard in opposite ear due to crossover via bone conduction)
 

  • In profound unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, bone conduction sound placed on the mastoid (of the deaf ear) may be perceived by the contralateral (healthy) cochlea.

  • This gives the illusion that bone conduction is better than air conduction in the affected ear → Rinne test is falsely negative.

  • It's not truly negative because the patient is not hearing via the tested cochlea.

    In This Case:

  • Initially, some hearing was preserved → Rinne positive

  • Now, after progression (fistula test now negative, suggesting permanent damage):

    • Profound sensorineural hearing loss has set in

    • Rinne test may appear negative even though it's not a true conductive loss

    • This makes it a false negative Rinne test



Reference:Diseases of Ear Nose and thorat-PL dhingra 7th edition page no 24

questions.text: What is the Battle sign?
questions.solution:
Battle Sign is:

  • Mastoid ecchymosis — bruising over the mastoid process (behind the ear).

  • It is a clinical sign of a basilar skull fracture, particularly involving the temporal bone.

  • Appears several hours after trauma.

  • Often associated with other signs of basilar skull fracture like:

    • Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymosis)

    • Hemotympanum

    • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea


      Other Options:

  1. Periorbital hematoma – Seen in raccoon eyes, another sign of basal skull fracture, but not Battle sign.

  2. Perichondritis – Inflammation of auricular cartilage, usually from trauma or infection (not a skull fracture sign).

  3. Bezold abscess – A deep neck abscess resulting from mastoiditis extension (not a sign of skull fracture).


Reference:Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery 7th Edition - Page no. 3495

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which ts pulsatile in nature. On examination, a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane and an audible bruit is heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinnie test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has classic features of a glomus tympanicum, a type of paraganglioma in the middle ear.

Key clinical clues:

  • Pulsatile tinnitus → hallmark of vascular tumors like glomus.

  • Slowly progressive conductive hearing loss → mass in middle ear interferes with ossicular chain.

  • Reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane → “rising sun” appearance seen with glomus tympanicum.

  • Audible bruit over mastoid → due to vascular nature of the tumor.

  • Rinne test negative → indicates conductive hearing loss (affected ear: bone > air conduction).

    Explanation of Other Options:

  • ASOM (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media): Sudden onset, with pain and fever; no pulsatile tinnitus or visible vascular mass.

  • CSOM (Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media): Associated with discharge and perforation, not a pulsatile mass.

  • Mastoiditis: Presents with postauricular pain/swelling and systemic signs, not a mass behind the tympanic membrane.

    Diagnosis:

Most likely: Glomus tympanicum (a type of glomus tumor) – benign but locally aggressive.


Reference: Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat-PL dhingra 7th edition page no 121-123

choices.text: Wait and watch for 4-5 days to allow spontaneous healing
Do an MRI to localize the leak and control the discharge endoscopically
Put a dural catheter to control CSF leak
Approach transcranial to repair the damaged frontobasal region

questions.text: A head injury victim was taken to the hospital. The patient was awake and had a clear nasal discharge coming out of his right nostril. An NCCT head was performed, and it indicated a frontobasal damage that could not be repaired. What type of management is ideal?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest it is a case of CSF rhinorrhoea (history of trauma and clear nasal discharge).
Treatment: Early cases of traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea are managed conservatively. (i.e. wait and watch )
Persistent nasal discharge is treated by endoscopic surgery of the area.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 184

questions.text: In the event of controlling epistaxis, which of the following vessels is not ligated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Internal carotid artery

Internal Carotid artery doesn’t contribute to kiesselbach plexus in the nose
To Manage Epistaxis following steps are done in sequential order until the bleeding is controlled.
Step1. Trotter’s or Hippocratic Method: Pinching the nose with thumb and index finger for 5 minutes while sitting and leaning forwards.
Stpe2. Cauterisation with Electro Cautery if the bleeding point can be localized
Step3. Anterior and Posterior nasal Packing
Step4. Endoscopically ligating Sphenopalatine artery followed by Maxillary artery and if still not controlled then external Carotid artery

questions.text: Target sign is seen in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
Target sign is seen in traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

In cases of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea there is damage to the cribriform plate of the fovea ethmoidalis. 
This trauma causes leakage of both CSF and blood, hence on blotting the discharge, two rings are seen of blood and CSF respectively.

In cases of increased ICP, only CSF discharge occurs, hence target sign is not seen.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 184

questions.text: Chronic nasal hemorrhage has been diagnosed in a 14-year-old boy. A peripheral smear revealed normocytic hypochromic anemia, and his hemoglobin level was 6.4 g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
With the given features the diagnosis can be concluded to that of Juvenile angiofibroma from the options. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a rare, benign tumor of the nasopharynx found mainly in 10-20 year old boys. JNA causes recurrent, unprovoked and profuse bleeding, at which point many patients present with severe anaemia. Spread of the tumor is limited to local invasion, by spreading to paranasal sinuses, pterygopalatine fossa, cheek, orbits and cranial cavity. CECT is the preferred investigation and MRI reveals any intracranial or infratemporal invasion.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 279

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with an antrochoanal polyp growing from the maxillary medial wall. Which of the following would be the patient's best course of action?
questions.solution:
The primary treatment for antrochoanal polyps is FESS, a functional endoscopic sinus surgery, which includes a polypectomy, uncinectomy and enlargement of the maxillary ostium. In some cases, such as where the polyp is arising from the floor, lateral wall, or anterior wall of the maxilla, the caldwell luc approach is added to the FESS. Medial maxillectomy is used primarily to remove inverted papillomas or limited malignancies of the lateral nasal wall.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 193

questions.text: Topical steroid use is not advised in?
questions.solution:
Topical steroids are not recommended in post-surgery for antrochoanal polyps.

The cause of antrochoanal polyps is infection, not allergies and thus Topical steroids are rarely advised. They are given post-surgery in ethmoidal polyp, allergic fungal sinusitis and chronic rhinosinusitis.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 195

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of nasal discharge, stuffiness, congestion, and anosmia. The woman also suffers from Asthma. The results of a para-nasal sinus CT scan are displayed below. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The correct option and the most likely diagnosis is option (3) Allergic Fungal Sinusitis (AFS).

This condition often affects individuals with asthma or a history of allergies. It is characterized by the presence of fungal material in the sinuses. The fungal elements can lead to chronic inflammation, and patients often present with nasal congestion, discharge, and anosmia, which matches the symptoms described.

On imaging, sinuses show complete opacification. Non contrast enhanced CT, the sinuses are opacified by centrally hyperdense material and have outer peripheral rim of hypodense mucosa. Thinning and sometimes erosion of sinus wall is also seen. 


Reference: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 504

questions.text:
An old woman is suffering from a blocked nose, nasal discharge, diplopia, and facial edema. Examination reveals a blackish discharge coming from the nose with necrosis of the palate, face skin, and nasal mucosa. Right globe fixation is present. Urinary ketones are positive and blood sugar is high. Which drug from the list below should be
administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
This diabetic patient is most likely suffering from mucormycosis, in which there is involvement of periorbital region and visual impairment. Amphotericin B deoxycholate remains the only licensed antifungal agent for the treatment of mucormycosis. Along with it Posaconazole could be given.

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding CSF leak is false
questions.solution:
• Option(4() is a false statement.
  • HRCT base of the skull is the best investigation for localizing the site of the leak not MRI. CT Cisternography in which dye is put intrathecally is done to localize the site during an active csf leak.
  • Other statements are True. 
Other options
  • Option 1 -  The cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone is ithe most common site for spontaneous or traumatic CSF leaks due to its thin structure and proximity to the nasal cavity. 
  • Option 2 -  Beta-2 transferrin is a protein found almost exclusively in CSF (and to a lesser extent in vitreous humor and perilymph). Its detection in nasal or ear fluid is a highly specific for CSF Rhinorrhoea. 
  • Option 3 - Intrathecal fluorescein, injected into the spinal subarachnoid space, is a well-established technique to localize the site of a CSF leak, particularly in complex cases. It is visualized under endoscopy or imaging as it leaks out.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 184

questions.solution:
Chemo and radiotherapy are the treatment of choice in Nasopharyngeal carcinoma. So, nasopharyngectomy with radial neck dissection is the incorrect answer. questions.text: Occipitomental x-ray view of paranasal sinuses with closed mouth is also known as
questions.solution:
The Water’s View X-ray position (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a useful examination technique utilized by physicians. In this technique, the X-ray beam is projected from behind while the patient places their nose and chin on the film with mouth closed. One of its recommended variations is the Pierre's view, which is preferred as it shows the sphenoid sinus more clearly when taken with an open mouth. It is great for evaluating nasal fractures, where one can clearly see the right and left nasal bones, along with their lateral displacement. Additionally, structures such as the maxillary sinuses, frontal sinuses, sphenoid sinus, lygoma, zygomatic arch, nasal bone, frontal process of maxilla, superior orbital fissure, and intratemporal fossa can be clearly seen with this technique.

If the question mentioned open mouth the answer would have been Pierre's view. 

Referece :https://www.instagram.com/neuronapp.in/p/CguiYhuBvhk/

questions.text: As management, partial closure of the nostrils is done in?
questions.solution:
Partial or full closure of the nostrils is done in the management of ozaena because it helps to reduce the amount of air that can enter the nose and sinus area. This helps to reduce the irritation and mucus that can occur in patients with ozaena, thus helping to decrease the severity of the condition. Additionally, the reduction in airflow through the nasal passages helps to reduce the chances of further infection or inflammation developing in the area.Partial or full closure of the nostrils is done in the management of ozaena because it helps to reduce the amount of air that can enter the nose and sinus area. This helps to reduce the irritation and mucus that can occur in patients with ozaena, thus helping to decrease the severity of the condition. Additionally, the reduction in airflow through the nasal passages helps to reduce the chances of further infection or inflammation developing in the area.

 

Young's operation is a surgical treatment used to treat conditions like chronic nasal obstruction and snoring. The procedure involves the closing of both nostrils with the use of elevated vestibule skin flaps. The nostrils are re-opened six months later when the mucosa has returned to normal.

 

Modified Young's operation is a variation of the procedure in which only partial closure is implemented, leaving a 2 mm hole in the nostril to reduce discomfort. 

 

Lastly, Lautenslager surgery is another surgical treatment that involves inserting fat, cartilage, and Teflon under the mucoperiosteum of the lateral wall in order to narrow the widened airway.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 173

questions.text:
A woman complains of nasal blockage and visits the ENT OPD.
Turbinate and septum covered by o/e greenish-black crust in nasal cavity.

questions.solution:
Merciful anosmia is the classical finding of atrophic rhinitis.
Roomy nasal cavity is also a feature of the same.
Atrophic rhinitis, also known as chronic atrophic rhinitis, is an ongoing inflammation of the nose that is characterised by the atrophy of the nasal mucosa, which includes the glands, turbinate bones, and nerve components that feed the nose. Primary and secondary chronic atrophic rhinitis are both possible. Females are most frequently affected by it. Patients from lower socioeconomic categories have reported it.
