questions.text: Which of the following sinuses is most likely to have mucoceles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Frontal
Mucoceles are most commonly found in the frontal sinus, followed by the ethmoid sinus. Frontal sinuses are particularly prone to mucoceles due to their complex drainage anatomy and higher likelihood of obstruction. Obstruction of the sinus outflow tract leads to mucus accumulation, expansion of the sinus, and erosion of surrounding bone.

Frontal sinusitis: Frontal headache/ Office Headache with tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus.
Maxillary Sinusitis: Frontal headache with tenderness around the maxillary bone.
Sphenoid Sinusitis: Post nasal discharge with occipital headache
Ethmoid sinusitis: Edema of eyelids and tenderness over the nasal bridge

questions.text: A known case of asthma presented to the ENT OPD with the complaints of chronic rhinorrhoea and nasal polyps. After evaluation, a diagnosis of Samter's triad was made. Which drug should be AVOIDED in such a patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided. 
 

Samter's Triad (also known as Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease, or AERD) is characterized by:

  1. Asthma
  2. Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps
  3. Sensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs

In patients with Samter's Triad, taking aspirin or other NSAIDs that inhibit cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) can trigger severe respiratory reactions, including bronchospasm, nasal congestion, or even life-threatening asthma attacks.

Other options:

  • Co-amoxiclav, penicillin, and cotrimoxazole are antibiotics and do not act on the COX pathway, so they do not pose the same risk as aspirin.

Management:
 
  • Avoid all COX-1 inhibiting NSAIDs.
  • Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is usually safe but should be used cautiously in sensitive individuals.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 193, 194.

questions.text: All of the following are smell perception tests except?
questions.solution:

  2. UP SIT (University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test) - A widely used standardized test for assessing olfactory function.
  3. CC SIT (Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test) - A variation of the UP SIT designed to be more culturally inclusive for testing olfactory perception.



Reference: Cuming's Otolaryngology,: Head and Neck Surgery, 6th edition, Page no 55.

Wrobel, Bozena B, and Donald A Leopold. “Clinical assessment of patients with smell and taste disorders.” Otolaryngologic clinics of North America vol. 37,6 (2004): 1127-42. doi:10.1016/j.otc.2004.06.010. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7118991/

In the first pass (endoscopic evaluation is done using a three-pass technique), the endoscope is passed along the nasal floor visualizing the septum and inferior turbinate, following which we enter the post-nasal space visualizing the eustachian tube, its orifice (option 3) and the Fossa of Rosenmuller.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page. No- 282.

questions.text: A 35y old farmer presents to the ENT with Unilateral obstruction of nasal cavity associated with nasal bleeding. On examination a mass was visualised. Biopsy was done which revealed Several sporangia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Rhinosporidiosis. It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium Seeberi. Most prevelant in rural areas.

Males more affected than females .
HPE shows several sporangia filled with spores.
Treatment -Surgical Excision

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page. No- 177, 178.

questions.text: 5y old male came with history of pain over the eye with diminution of vision with history of URTI symptoms. The CT scan is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of URTI with painful diminution of vision and CT is suggestive of Sub Periosteal abscess mostly secondary due to Ethmoid Sinusitis. The CT shows rim enhancing lesion adjanccent to lamina papyracea with fat plance between


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page. No: 225.

questions.text: A male patient presents with nasal obstruction, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and loss of smell. Endoscopic findings are shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and endoscopic findings suggests a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the nose characterized by the atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact cause remains unknown, but it is more prevalent in females and typically begins around puberty.

Patients commonly present with nasal obstruction, foul odors, and merciful anosmia, which refers to a significant loss of smell that prevents them from detecting the unpleasant odor from their nose.

Treatment Options:
• Nasal Irrigation: Warm saline or an alkaline solution made of 1 part sodium bicarbonate, 1 part sodium biborate, and 2 parts sodium chloride in 280 mL of water.
• Local Antibiotics: Kemicetine antiozena solution, which contains chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
• Additional Treatments: 25% glucose in glycerin, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, and placental extract.
Surgical Management:
• Young's Operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule, and both nostrils are completely closed for 6 months. This allows the mucosa to potentially revert to normal and reduces crusting.

• Modified Young's Operation: This variation involves partial closure of the nostrils to minimize discomfort while achieving similar results to the original Young's operation.

• Narrowing of the Nasal Cavity: This can be achieved through submucosal injection of Teflon paste or by inserting fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

These treatments aim to alleviate symptoms and improve the quality of life for patients suffering from atrophic rhinitis.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is antral lavage not indicated?
questions.solution:
Antral lavage (maxillary sinus washout) is a minor ENT procedure used to drain and irrigate the maxillary sinus through the inferior meatus.

It is indicated in:

  • Diagnosis of chronic maxillary sinusitis (to collect pus for culture/sensitivity).

  • Treatment of chronic maxillary sinusitis (when medical therapy fails).

  • To obtain specimens from the antrum for diagnostic purposes.

However, it is not indicated in acute maxillary sinusitis, because:

  • The mucosa is acutely inflamed and edematous, increasing the risk of spread of infection, bleeding, and facial cellulitis.

  • Acute cases are managed medically with antibiotics, decongestants, and steam inhalation.

Hence, antral lavage is contraindicated in acute maxillary sinusitis.

questions.text: A patient presents with the findings as shown in the image below. What is the most likely voice abnormality that would be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above indicates adenoid hypertrophy, a condition commonly seen in children. Patients typically present with rhinolalia clausa, characterized by a loss of nasal tone in their voice.

Key Features of Adenoid Hypertrophy:
• Causes: Often occurs in response to allergens or infections.
• Symptoms:
Nasal obstruction
Sinusitis
Rhinolalia clausa (altered voice quality)
• Cognitive Effects: Children may experience aprosexia, which leads to difficulties concentrating and declining academic performance.

Characteristic Appearance:
Children with adenoid hypertrophy may exhibit adenoid facies, which includes:
• Dull expression
• Open mouth
• Hitched-up upper lip
• Pinched-in nose
• High arched palate
• Crowded upper teeth
These features help in identifying the condition and guiding appropriate management.

questions.text: The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the sinuses. What is the common name of this view?
questions.solution:
Indications:
This view is typically used for evaluating conditions such as acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
Visible Structures:
In the Towne's view, the following structures can be observed:
Bilateral Petrous Pyramids: Allows for comparison between sides.
Arcuate Eminence and Superior Semicircular Canal: Important for assessing inner ear anatomy.
Mastoid Antrum: Part of the mastoid process.
Internal Auditory Canal: Contains the vestibulocochlear nerve and facial nerve.
Tympanic Cavity: Middle ear space.
Cochlea: Critical for hearing.
External Auditory Canal: Pathway to the eardrum.

choices.text: Blood supply is mostly from the external carotid artery

questions.text: A boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign are indeed indicative of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a benign but locally invasive tumor. 

Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma:
Origin: Typically arises from the sphenopalatine foramen, extending into the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, pterygopalatine fossa, pterygomaxillary fossa, and infratemporal fossa.

Demographics: Predominantly affects adolescent males, usually between the ages of 10 and 20 years.

Histopathology: Characterized by a hamartomatous mass of vascular tissue that becomes an angiofibroma, believed to be influenced by testosterone.

Clinical Presentation: Patients may present with nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and possibly facial deformities or swelling due to the tumor's growth.

Diagnosis:
Imaging: CT scans are crucial for assessing the extent of the tumor and its relationship with surrounding structures.

Biopsy: The statement that "biopsy is the investigation of choice" is incorrect. Biopsy is typically avoided due to the high risk of significant bleeding associated with this highly vascular tumor.

Treatment:
Management: Treatment often involves surgical excision, and preoperative embolization may be performed to reduce vascularity and minimize bleeding risk during surgery.
Understanding these aspects is essential for proper diagnosis and management of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically seen in Allergic Rhinitis?
questions.solution:
• Otta Veraguth Fold is a Physical sign of Depression.
  • Allergic rhinitis can have
  1. Allergic Salute- Black Transverse nasal crease on dorsum of nose due to rubbing,
  2. Allergic Shiners and Dennie Morgan lines. Below is the image of Allergic salute and Dennie Morgan Line.

Physical signs of depression
Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page No 194-195.

questions.text: A 15y old male presents with unilateral Nasal Obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis for the past six months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis based on the history is Juvenile Nasal AngioFibroma.
  • Usually presents with
  1. Reccurent Epistaxis,
  2. Nasal Mass and
  3. Obstruction in adolescent male.
  • CT finding-Holman Miller sign or Antral sign- Anterior Bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Surgical excision is treatment of choice


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page No 289-295.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with gradual swelling on the left side of his face for the past two weeks. He has a history of a wood injury two months ago. A CECT of the nose and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass in the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. A biopsy of the specimen shows a foreign body granuloma with positive PAS and GMS stains. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described strongly suggests mucormycosis (phycomycosis). A positive fungal stain, specifically Grocott-Gomori‘smethenamine silver (GMS) stain, supports this diagnosis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection caused by molds in the order Mucorales, which include the genera Rhizopus, Mucor, and Absidia. These fungi are ubiquitous and thermotolerant, commonly found in air and dust.

In immunocompetent individuals, mucormycosis can manifest as isolated cutaneous or subcutaneous infections following trauma with soil or vegetation. The disease is highly invasive, often penetrating into muscle, fascia, and bone due to the fungi‘s angio-invasive properties. Although the lungs are typically the primary site of infection, rhinocerebralmucormycosis is common in individuals with diabetic ketoacidosis. This form begins with eye and facial pain, progressing to orbital cellulitis, proptosis, and potential vision loss, with a characteristic black necrotic mass in the nasal cavity.

Diagnosis involves:

Exudate Examination: A wet preparation in 10% potassium hydroxide reveals broad, ribbon-like hyphae.

Tissue Analysis: Hematoxylin and eosin staining shows broad, non-septate hyphae, often invading blood vessels. Special stains can identify the fungus in tissue sections.

Biopsy: Confirms the diagnosis by showing non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucorales like Rhizopusdelemar. These hyphae are broad (10-15 µm), uneven in thickness, irregularly branched, and sparsely septate.

Culture: Isolation on Sabouraud agar (with antibacterial agents but without cycloheximide) yields grey-white colonies with a thick, cottony surface.


Treatment involves primarily liposomal amphotericin B and is complemented by surgical debridement of affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing conditions.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 229-230 .

questions.text: Identify the nerve block shown in the image
questions.solution:
The nasociliary nerve block is performed by inserting the needle approximately 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye. The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, which itself is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Branches of the nasociliary nerve include:
  1. Long ciliary nerves: Provide sensory innervation to the cornea, ciliary body, and iris.
  2. Ramus communicans to the ciliary ganglion: Contributes to the sensory functions of the eye.
  3. Posterior ethmoidal nerve: Supplies sensory innervation to the frontal sinus and the posterior ethmoidal air cells.
  4. Anterior ethmoidal nerve: Provides sensory innervation to the middle and anterior ethmoidal cells and the lateral part of the nasal septum.
  5. Infratrochlear nerve: A continuation of the nasociliary nerve that innervates the conjunctiva, lacrimal sac, caruncle, and the medial part of the eyelids.


The nasociliary nerve block is used in various procedures, including:
 
  • Surgery for nasal fractures
  • Septoplasty
  • Rhinoplasty
  • Repair of skin lacerations



Reference: Miller's anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2412-2414.

questions.text: A South Indian male cattle breeder presents with intermittent, severe nosebleeds. An examination of the nose was conducted, and a biopsy was performed, with histopathological examination revealing specific findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical image depicting a polyp, along with histopathological findings showing numerous sporangia, suggests rhinosporidiosis.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 185-186 .

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The sinus marked in the non-contrast CT image is the maxillary sinus. Maxillary sinus is the largest pair of paranasal sinuses, it is pyramidal in shape and it opens into the middle meatus. It is present since birth.

Paranasal sinuses are air-filled cavities in the bones of the skull, divided into two groups:

Anterior group:
  • Maxillary sinus (also known as the Antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinus
All of these sinuses open into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity, and their ostia lie anterior to the basal lamella of the middle turbinate.

Posterior group:
  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses, which open into the superior meatus.
Sphenoid sinus, which opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman takes aspirin for a headache, later she presented with wheezing and breathlessness. These symptoms are likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette suggests development of wheezing and breathlessness (asthma like features), upon taking aspirin. This is a key feature of Samter's triad, also known as aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease or aspirin-induced asthma.

It is a non-IgE mediated hypersensitivity reaction to aspirin or other cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors. Samter's triad consists of:

1. Nasal polyposis
2. Bronchial asthma
3. Aspirin intolerance

Management:

Avoidance of aspirin and NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1 is crucial to prevent triggering the hypersensitivity reaction.
Treatment may involve aspirin desensitization and endoscopic sinus surgery to manage nasal polyps and improve symptoms.

Other Options:

Option A: Extrinsic Asthma refers to asthma which is triggered by some form of allergen. It is the most common type of asthma and it mostly starts during childhood. It has no relation to aspirin intake.

Option C: Although Drug interaction could also occur due to aspirin intake, it would result in symptoms similar to an anaphylactic reaction, such as facial flushing, swelling of lips and tongue, and breathlessness with stridor. However, the presence of wheeze in the question stem is more suggestive of asthma like presentation than anaphylaxis.

Option D: Samter's Triad is a non-Ig E mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Therefore, this option is incorrect. 

Mnemonic: “ASPIRIN” to remember adverse effects of aspirin

questions.text: A 2-year-old was brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last few hours. The X-ray is given below. Which is the next best step to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the child with difficulty swallowing, along with the provided X-rays, suggests the presence of a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin or disc battery.

Key Points:

The X-rays consist of anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the chest and neck. Coins, disc batteries, and small toy items are frequently ingested by children.

In the AP view, the flat surface of a coin in the esophagus is visible, indicating it is oriented in the coronal plane. In contrast, the edge of the coin can be seen on the lateral view. Coins in the esophagus typically lie in the coronal plane, whereas coins in the trachea are oriented in the sagittal plane.

Common symptoms include choking, gagging, and coughing, followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), refusal to eat, vomiting, and neck or throat pain. If the foreign body exerts pressure on the larynx or tracheal wall, respiratory distress may occur.

Imaging studies, including posterior-anterior (PA) and lateral views of the chest and abdomen, are recommended for accurate diagnosis.

Treatment involves the removal of the foreign body via esophagoscopy.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral nasal obstruction associated with watery nasal discharge and bleeding. A diagnosis of inverted papilloma is made. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor) is a benign but locally invasive tumor that arises from the lateral wall of the nasal cavity, often from the middle meatus. It is associated with a high rate of local recurrence and has malignant potential (can transform into squamous cell carcinoma in ~5–15% of cases).

Key Features of Inverted Papilloma:

  • Nature – Benign but locally aggressive and invasive

  • Origin – Arises from the lateral nasal wall near the middle meatus

  • Symptoms – Presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and watery nasal discharge

  • Imaging (CT/MRI) – Shows bone remodeling or destruction, indicating invasive potential

  • Histology – Characterized by endophytic (inverted) growth of epithelium into the underlying stroma

  • Malignant potential – Risk of malignant transformation to squamous cell carcinoma in 5–15% of cases

  • Treatment – Surgical excision, commonly via endoscopic medial maxillectomy

  • Recurrence – High if excision is incomplete


Ringertz Criteria (for Malignancy in Inverted Papilloma):
These criteria help distinguish benign inverted papilloma from squamous cell carcinoma arising in inverted papilloma:

  • Areas of typical benign inverted papilloma – Must be demonstrable somewhere in the lesion to confirm its origin.

  • Transition zone – A clear transition must be seen from benign inverted papilloma epithelium to malignant epithelium.

  • Malignant features – Lesion should show features of squamous cell carcinoma such as:

    • Cellular atypia

    • Increased mitotic activity

    • Keratinization

    • Invasion into stroma

questions.text: A patient presents with thick nasal discharge and headache. Examination reveals hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate with a mulberry appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical case points to hypertrophic rhinitis, a condition marked by the thickening of the nasal mucosa, submucosa, seromucous glands, periosteum, and bone.

Causes of Hypertrophic Rhinitis:
Recurrent nasal infections
Chronic sinusitis
Chronic nasal irritation (e.g., due to smoking, prolonged use of nasal drops)
Vasomotor and allergic rhinitis
Exposure to industrial irritants

Clinical Features:
Thick, sticky nasal discharge
Headache and transient anosmia (temporary loss of smell)
Examination reveals hypertrophy of the turbinates, particularly the inferior turbinate, with underlying fibrosis.
Mulberry hypertrophy, where the turbinates become enlarged and nodular, is a typical finding.

Treatment Options:
Cryosurgery of the turbinates
Linear cauterization
Submucosal diathermy
Partial or total turbinectomy
Use of lasers for targeted treatment

Other options:

  • Nasal polyp → pale, glistening, grape-like mass.

  • Common cold → acute catarrhal inflammation, no mulberry appearance.

  • Atrophic rhinitis → roomy nasal cavity, foul-smelling crusts, not hypertrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, the condition least likely to cause mucormycosis is the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection predominantly seen in patients with diabetes mellitus and those who are immunocompromised. Recently, it has emerged as a significant superinfection among COVID-19 patients, particularly in India, largely due to underlying diabetes and the use of steroids.

Risk factors for mucormycosis include:

Uncontrolled diabetes
Acidosis (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
Steroid treatment
Lymphomas and leukemias
Immunodeficiencies
Severe burns
The most common form of mucormycosis is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Patients typically present with symptoms such as rhinitis, facial pain, and facial numbness, which may progress to conjunctival suffusion, swelling, and blurry vision.

Patients may experience local tissue destruction accompanied by blackish nasal discharge, resembling the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The dark coloration results from direct fungal invasion, leading to arterial and venous thrombosis and subsequent gangrene.

Diagnosis is established through biopsy and histopathological examination, which reveals characteristic wide, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

Treatment involves the intravenous administration of amphotericin B and surgical excision of necrotic tissue, along with addressing any underlying conditions and risk factors.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with recurrent epistaxis There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the left posterior choanae. Which of the following is the most appropriate for the managerment of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The most probable diagnosis is Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgical excision is the most appropriate step in its management.

• Adolescent male presenting with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx points towards angiofibroma. The consistency of the tumor is firm but the digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, because of the risk of profuse bleeding.

• Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head with contrast enhancement is now the investigation of choice. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.

questions.text: The structure marked in the given diagram contains which of the following
questions.solution: The marked structure is the Pterygopalatine fossa which contains the Pterygopalatine ganglion. It is a parasympathetic ganglion responsible for parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal gland, nasal glands, and palatine glands. Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers originate from the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and travel through the greater petrosal nerve. These fibres join with the deep petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal before synapsing in the ganglion. Ref- PL Dhingra Diseases of ENT 8th edition Page 289-290

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident a young girl presented with a fracture as shown in the X-ray. Which of the following symptoms would she suffer from ?
questions.solution: The structure marked in the given image is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid and fracture to the cribriform plate will lead to anosmia and may also lead to a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak, manifesting as clear, watery nasal discharge - CSF rhinorrhea. Ref- PL Dhingra disease of ENT 6th edition Page 163

choices.text: surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should be carried out
Beta-2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CS rhinorrhea.
High-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice
Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause

questions.text: A 30 year old female following a road traffic accident presented with blood stained watery nasal discharge. Which of the following is false regarding the condition.
questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinnorhea. It refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose. It can occur as clear fluid or be mixed with blood, particularly in cases of acute head injuries. Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause of this. Beta-2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CS rhinorrhea. High-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice for localizing, the site of the leak. Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done as it increases chances of meningitis. P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery - 8th Edition • Page nos: 191-193

questions.text: Homan Miller sign is seen in which of the following condition given below ?
questions.solution:
Homan Miller sign is seen in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It occurs due to anterior bowing of the maxillary sinus. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. JNA accounts for only 0.05% of all head and neck tumours. Patients usually present with a triad of progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis and a mass in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.
It has the potential to cause proptosis, affecting both the orbit and intracranial extension, eventually leading to cranial nerve palsies and loss of vision.
Angiofibroma can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and magnetic resonance angiography. Anterior bowing of the maxillary wall due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space on CT known as the Holman-Miller sign is a characteristic finding of JNA. Recurrence has been reported up to 35%. Management: Surgical excision is the treatment of choice.
Recurrent angiofibroma is treated with revision surgery, Radiotherapy is considered where the recurrence tumour is inaccessible. Ref- PL Dhingra 7th edition ENT page 279-281

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Trotter's triad seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Trotter's triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. It consists of consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to invasion of levator palatini muscles.
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition • Page no. 270

questions.text: Which of the following Staging system is used in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.solution: Fisch staging is used in Juvenile Nasal Angiofibroma. Ref- PL dhingra disease of ENT 8th edition Page 293

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction. On examination, an irregular mass was visualized in the nasal cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An antrochoanal polyp, a non-neoplastic nasal polyp made of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa, is the most likely diagnosis. It grows out of the antrum and into the nasal cavity and choana after emerging from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum close to its accessory ostium. It usually manifests as a single, unilateral growth that is more typical of young adults and children.

The polyp is divided into three parts:

1. A slender antral stem

2. A globular, spherical choanal portion,

3. A section of the nose that is flat.

Clinically, it manifests as a hyponasal voice, mucoid nasal discharge, and unilateral nasal blockage. In more severe situations, the polyp could stick out of the nasal cavity and look pink and swollen. It is pliable and malleable.

Reference
Disease of Ear, Nose and Throat - PL Dhingra - 7th Edition - Page no 171,193, 451,549

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. There is no history of trauma or fall. He gives a history of unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
• The Holman-Miller sign is a classic radiological feature of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).

  • On CT imaging, it shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus due to the mass in the nasopharynx extending through the sphenopalatine foramen.

  • This sign is pathognomonic for JNA and helps differentiate it from other nasopharyngeal masses.

Remarks:

  • Teardrop sign: Sometimes used synonymously, but Holman-Miller is more specific.

  • Hanging drop sign: Seen in orbital rhabdomyosarcoma.

  • Aquino sign: Not commonly referenced.


Reference
PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition - Page no: 206, 279

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination of the nose, she has roomy nasal cavities, foul-smelling discharge, and dry greenish crusts. She is also found to have merciful anosmia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with:

    • Nasal obstruction

    • Foul-smelling nasal discharge with dry crusts

    • Enlarged (roomy) nasal cavities

    • Merciful anosmia (loss of smell but patient unaware)

  • These features are classic for atrophic rhinitis, a chronic condition characterized by:

    • Thinning of nasal mucosa

    • Atrophy of turbinates

    • Secondary bacterial colonization leading to foul odor

Other options:

  • Foreign body: Usually unilateral in children, may cause foul discharge but not roomy nasal cavities or anosmia.

  • Nasal polyps: Pale, edematous masses; usually associated with allergic rhinitis; discharge is not foul-smelling.

  • Allergic rhinitis: Causes nasal obstruction and watery discharge, but no foul odor or crusting.


Reference
Disease of Ear, Nose and Throat - PL Dhingra - 7th Edition - Page no: 172,173,181, 187, 193

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, blood-coloured nasal discharge. On examination, there is septal perforation. Biopsy from the nose shows necrosis and non-caseating granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with:

    • Hemoptysis → pulmonary involvement

    • Blood-stained nasal discharge and septal perforation → upper respiratory tract involvement

    • Biopsy showing necrosis and non-caseating granulomas → characteristic histopathology

  • Wegener's granulomatosis (GPA) is a small-to-medium vessel vasculitis affecting:

    • Upper airways (nose, sinuses)

    • Lungs

    • Kidneys (glomerulonephritis)

  • c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) is usually positive in active disease.

Other options:

  • Sarcoidosis: Non-caseating granulomas but rarely causes septal perforation or hemoptysis.

  • Leprosy: Causes nasal involvement, but no lung hemoptysis and granulomas are different.

  • Tuberculosis: Causes caseating granulomas, not non-caseating, and usually no septal perforation in early disease.


Reference
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery - 8th Edition - Page no 187

questions.text: Bulla ethmoidalis drains into which among the following?
questions.solution:
The ethmoidal cell known as Bulla ethmoidalis is located behind the uncinate process. It drains to the middle meatus and forms the posterior border of the hiatus semilunaris.
Reference
Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat -PL Dhingra6th Edition - Page no. 137

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with difficulty breathing. It is noted that his symptoms improve when he cries. In which disease does the symptom improve upon crying?
questions.solution:
• A newborn is an obligate nasal breather.

  • In choanal atresia (especially bilateral), the posterior nasal opening is blocked, so the baby has difficulty breathing at rest.

  • When the baby cries, the mouth opens, allowing air entry → symptoms improve with crying.

Other options:

  • Acute rhinosinusitis → not seen in newborns, presents with fever + nasal congestion.

  • Allergic rhinitis → presents later in childhood with sneezing, nasal itching, watery rhinorrhea.

  • Atrophic rhinitis → occurs in older children/adults, not in newborns.


Reference
Disease of Ear, Nose and Throat - PL Dhingra - 7th Edition - Page no. 47, 183, 199

questions.text: Which artery is most commonly affected in bleeding from the nose?
questions.solution:
Locations of Epistaxis

Ninety percent of incidences of epistaxis occur in Little's Area. It is distinguished by a vascular plexus called "Kiesselbach's plexus," which is situated just above the vestibule in the antero-inferior region of the nasal septum. This area is especially vulnerable to air drying effects and abrasion from fingernails.

Above the Middle Turbinate Level: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries, which are a component of the internal carotid system, are typically the source of bleeding in this region.

Below the Middle Turbinate Level: The sphenopalatine artery's branches are usually the source of bleeding in this case.

Blood may enter the pharynx in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, often known as the nasopharynx.

Woodruff's Venous Plexus: posterior epistaxis is linked to this location.

Reference
PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition - Page 198

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Trotter’s triad is a classic set of three clinical features that occur due to tumor infiltration in the nasopharynx, particularly affecting adjacent nerves and the Eustachian tube.

Components of Trotter’s Triad:

  1. Conductive Hearing Loss

    • Due to Eustachian tube blockage from tumor mass, leading to otitis media with effusion.

  2. Ipsilateral Temporoparietal Neuralgia

    • Pain in the region supplied by the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve due to perineural invasion.

  3. Palatal Paralysis

    • Due to involvement of the pharyngeal branch of cranial nerve X (vagus nerve), leading to nasal regurgitation or nasal speech.


Reference:PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head And Neck Surgery 7th edition page no 285

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Examination revealed smooth rounded swellings on either side of the septum, through both the nares. On palpation, it was soft and fluctuant. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This child has features suggestive of a septal hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the nasal septum and its mucoperichondrium, usually following trauma (like a fall).

Key Clinical Features of Septal Hematoma:

  • Smooth, rounded bilateral swelling on both sides of the nasal septum

  • Soft and fluctuant on palpation

  • Causes nasal obstruction/difficulty breathing

  • History of trauma

  • May appear as boggy swelling in both nares

    Why is it an Emergency?

  • If not promptly drained, it can lead to:

    • Cartilage necrosis (due to compromised blood supply)

    • Saddle-nose deformity

    • Infection → septal abscess

    • Intracranial complications (rare but possible)

      Next Best Step: Incision and Drainage

  • Immediate surgical drainage to remove the hematoma

  • Followed by nasal packing and antibiotics to prevent infection

    Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • Systemic antibiotics: May be needed after drainage, but not sufficient alone

  • CT scan: Not required for classic clinical diagnosis

  • Submucosal resection: Not indicated; this is done for chronic septal deviation, not acute hematoma


Reference:Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat -PL Dhingra 6th edition page no 168

choices.text: It is situated at the postero-inferior part of the nasal septum
Keisselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to the Little's area?
questions.solution:
Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s area) is a richly vascular region on the antero-inferior part of the nasal septum.

  • It is the most common site of epistaxis (nosebleed).

  • Contains the Kiesselbach's plexus, which is an anastomosis of 5 arteries:

    1. Anterior ethmoidal artery (from ophthalmic)

    2. Sphenopalatine artery (from maxillary)

    3. Greater palatine artery (from maxillary)

    4. Superior labial artery (from facial)

    5. Septal branch of the facial artery

      Incorrect Options:

  1. It is situated at the postero-inferior part of the nasal septum
    → Incorrect: It is at the antero-inferior part.

  2. Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here
    → Incorrect: There are 5 arteries involved.

  3. Least common site for epistaxis
    → Incorrect: It is actually the most common site.



Reference: Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat-PL dhingra 6th edition page no 176

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that typically affects:

  • Adolescent males (10–25 years)

  • Presents with:

    • Recurrent epistaxis (due to vascularity)

    • Nasal obstruction

    • Rhinorrhea

    • Sometimes facial swelling or proptosis in advanced cases

On examination, a firm, reddish-blue (purplish) mass is seen in the posterior nasal cavity/nasopharynx.

Key clues:

  • Age: 14 years → Classic age group

  • Gender: Male → Almost exclusively in males

  • Recurrent epistaxis → Common presenting symptom

  • Nasal obstruction, rhinorrhea → Due to mass effect

  • Purplish mass in nasopharynx → Typical vascular tumor appearance


Incorrect options: 

  1. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
    → More common in adults, especially males from Southeast Asia; presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and nasal symptoms.

  2. Pyogenic granuloma
    → Highly vascular lesion but occurs on skin or oral mucosa, rarely in the posterior nasopharynx.

  3. Rhabdomyosarcoma
    → A possibility in children but less common; may not present with such typical signs and is usually more aggressive.


Reference:PL Dhingra diseases of ear nose and throat and Head And Neck surgery 7th edition page no 279-281

questions.text:
A woman approaches with a history of experiencing burning after eating spicy meals. On inspection, the buccal mucosa has bilateral white lacy streaks.
Although the third molar is amalgamated, there is no history of tobacco addiction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
White lacy lines (Wickham's striae) with a history of amalgamated molar is suggestive of Lichen planus.
               
Lichen Planus
 

  • Cutaneous lesions of lichen planus consist of itchy, violaceous, flat-topped papules that may coalesce focally to form plaques
  • It is also referred to as pruritic, purple, polygonal papules
  • These papules are often highlighted by white dots or lines called 'Wickham striae', representing the clinical correlates of zones of hypergranulosis, that typify lesions histologically.
  • Multiple lesions are characteristic and are symmetrically distributed; particularly on the extremities, often about the wrists and elbow, and on the glans penis

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 247

questions.text: The second primary tumour of the head and neck is the most commonly suspected malignant tumor of:
questions.solution:
Second primary malignancy of head and neck is a term used to describe a cancer that develops after a patient has been treated for a cancerous tumor that originated in the head or neck. This type of cancer is most commonly associated with the oral cavity, which includes the lips, tongue, floor of the mouth, hard and soft palate, cheeks, and gums. This type of cancer is more common in patients who have had prior radiation therapy or chemotherapy for a malignancy in the head and neck area. The risk of second primary malignancy of the head and neck is increased if the patient is a smoker or has frequent sun exposure.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 258

questions.text: What is the treatment for recurrent URTI in a 5-year-old child with ear problems and mouth breathing?
questions.solution:
Adenoid hypertrophy is caused by enlarged adenoid tissue, which is located in the back of the nose. Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, nasal obstruction and hearing impairment often accompany adenoid hypertrophy. People with high arched palates are more likely to suffer from adenoid hypertrophy than those with normal palates. The most common management for adenoid hypertrophy is adenoidectomy, which is a surgical procedure to remove the excess adenoid tissue. Grommet insertion may also be used to further improve the symptoms associated with adenoid hypertrophy, such as hearing impairment, by helping to drain the ear wax and other secretions from middle ear.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 276

questions.text: A 5 years old child presents with voice change and stridor. Identify the abnormality marked on the fiberoptic laryngoscopy:
questions.solution:
Respiratory papillomatosis is a recurrent condition, common in children and presents with respiratory polyps. Respiratory papillomas are caused by the human papilloma virus (HPV). JORRP (Juvenile-onset) is more common and more severe than AORRP (Adult onset). JORRP is caused by exposure to HPV during the peripartum period. They're usually benign (non-cancerous). These growths can lead to vocal cord damage and airway problems. Because the virus is in the tissue, respiratory papillomas tend to reoccur even after they are removed. Treatment is laser resection of tumours.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a child who presented with fever and dysphagia with the following visualization.
questions.solution:
Peritonsillar Abscess is a common condition affecting the area around the tonsils. It occurs when bacteria or other infectious organisms, mostly GABHS, get trapped in the space between the tonsil and its covering membrane. It is frequently accompanied by fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and an asymmetric tonsillar bulge with displacement of the uvula away from the affected side. This clinical picture is highly diagnostic of Peritonsillar Abscess, which is treated with antibiotics and, in some cases, surgical drainage.

A particular kind of diverticulum called Zenker's diverticulum forms in the hypopharynx, usually in the space between the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle and the cricopharyngeus (CP) muscle. It is a false diverticulum since it only affects the mucosa and submucosal layers and not the muscle layer.

questions.text:
6-year-old boy who underwent surgery for recurrent tonsillitis had an uneventful recovery period.
The following morning, he experienced some minor mouth bleeding. WHat is the most likely source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
complications of tonsillectomy 

Immediate complications 

  • Bleeding (2-4%): On the table, gauze pressure or ligation are used to control primary haemorrhage. Trauma to a paratonsillar vein or aberrant vessel can cause excessive bleeding, or due to an underlying infection, hypertension, or bleeding disease. 
  • Trauma: soft palate, uvula, tonsils, lips, and teeth. Rarely, cervical injuries could happen. 

Delayed complications 

1. Hemorrhage: 

Reactionary haemorrhage might happen within 48 hours (incidence: 0.5–1%). 

It results from: 

Postoperative increase in blood pressure; 

Dislodgement of clot. 

Secondary haemorrhage (incidence 1%).

It typically happens between days 5-7 due to infection. 

2. Otalgia 

3. granuloma of intubation 

4. nightmares 

5. Pulmonary complications 

6. Change of voice 

7. Chronic granular pharyngitis

8. Dislocation of the tympanic membrane (TM) joint.

choices.text: Take to OT, remove the clot and re-ligation

questions.text: An older man appears with dysphagia, regurgitation, foul breath, and a cough. On inspection, there is evidence of bilateral lung crept. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Zenker's diverticulum

Zenker’s diverticulum arises from Killian’s triangle which is between the thyropharyngeus (supplied by Pharyngeal Plexus) and cricopharyngeus (supplied by RLN) part of the Inferior constrictor muscle. It is a false diverticulum (only mucosa and submucosa) and occurs commonly in the elderly. Neuromuscular incoordination during swallowing leads to herniation through Killian's dehiscence due to increased pressure. Dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation and aspiration are common presentations.

On local examination, a pink mass was seen obstructing the choana, as shown in the image below. Contrast CT scan enhanced uptake of contrast. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with recurrent epistaxis and unilateral nasal blockade with contrast enhanced CT showing a growth along with trans-nasal endoscopic image goes in favor of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.
 
  • It is a benign but locally aggressive tumor seen in adolescent males.
  • It arises from posterior part of nasal cavity near the region of sphenopalatine foramen. \
 
  • Investigation of choice- Contrast enhanced CT scan. ( Biopsy is contraindicated )
  • Staging system used- Radkowski 
 
  • Treatment- Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolisation of vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during surgery.
  • Radiotherapy, Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy can also be considered.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 153, 175, 193, 279-281.

choices.text: Use of flexible bronchoscope is indicated in management
If there is decreased air entry on right side, it suggests foreign body
In complete obstruction, Ball valve effect is the mechanism responsible for hyperinflation of right lung
Clinical diagnosis is of croup is made

questions.text: A 3years old child presented to the emergency department with difficulty in breathing. Chest X-ray was done and it showed hyperinflation of right side, left side being normal. True statement related to this clinical picture:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of aspirated foreign body. Among the given options, the correct statement is option 2.
 

Foreign bodies are more likely to enter the right bronchus because it is wider and more aligned with the tracheal lumen. The initial evaluation typically involves a plain chest X-ray in posteroanterior and lateral views, with expiratory films being particularly useful. These may reveal:

  • The size, shape, and location of a radio-opaque foreign body.
  • In cases of complete airway obstruction, lobar or segmental atelectasis.
  • In incomplete airway obstruction, the ball valve mechanism occurs when a foreign body partially blocks a bronchus, allowing air to enter but not exit. This results in hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area, particularly visible on expiratory X-ray films as trapped air cannot escape.

Management of airway foreign bodies includes:

  • Laryngeal foreign bodies: The Heimlich maneuver should be attempted first. If unsuccessful, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy may be necessary.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea or bronchi: These are removed using a rigid bronchoscope after ensuring adequate hydration and gastric emptying.
  • Antibiotics are administered as needed to prevent secondary infections.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 365-367.

Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 368, 390.

questions.text: Foreign entry in laryngeal inlet is prevented by cough reflex. Reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured damaged?
questions.solution:
• Here is the physiology behind cough:
  • When triggered, impulses travel via the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve which stems from the vagus nerve (CN X) to the medulla of the brain. This is the afferent neural pathway.
 
  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (ILN) is responsible for sensory innervation to the mucosa of the laryngeal inlet, epiglottis, and the upper part of the vocal cords. It detects foreign entry and triggers the cough reflex.
  • If this nerve is damaged or its function is impaired (e.g., by alcohol ingestion or other conditions), the reflex becomes sluggish, leading to an increased risk of aspiration.



Other options:
 

  1. ELN (External branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve): Provides motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle and does not play a sensory role in the laryngeal inlet.
  2. RLN (Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve): Supplies motor innervation to most intrinsic laryngeal muscles and sensory innervation below the vocal cords, but it’s not directly involved in detecting foreign entry at the laryngeal inlet.
  3. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX): Supplies sensation to the oropharynx and is involved in the gag reflex but not the cough reflex at the laryngeal inlet.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 335, 347-351.

questions.text: What is the stage of the laryngeal carcinoma shown in the CT?
questions.solution:
T4a stage represents tumor involving tissues beyond the larynx and/or laryngeal cartilage (eg: deep extrinsic tongue muscles, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus). The arrows shown represent the transmural spread of the tumor across the thyroid cartilage.
 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 358,360 .

questions.text:
A child has a biphasic stridor on auscultation. The following are the radiographic findings. What is the diagnosis?

 
1. Acute epiglottitis
2. Foreign body
3. Croup
4. Laryngomalacia
questions.solution:
Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis and cervical trachea.
The image shows the AP view of a plain radiograph of the neck of a child showing a ‘steeple sign’ suggestive of croup, also called acute laryngotracheobronchitis which is caused by Parainfluenza Virus.
Management includes- Racemic Epinephrine nebulization, Dexamethasone in leaser invasive route.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page. No- 328.

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive hoarseness and loss of voice, dysphagia and difficulty breathing. The patient has undergone an operation. Identify what procedure has been done.
questions.solution:
The patient with hoarseness progressing to loss of voice, dysphagia and difficulty breathing likely underwent surgical management with a permanent tracheostomy (shown in the image) for laryngeal cancer.

Total laryngectomy:
The entire larynx including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles and one or more rings of trachea are removed. Pharyngeal wall is repaired and lower tracheal stump sutured to the skin for breathing.

Total laryngectomy is indicated in the following conditions:
(i) T3 lesions (i.e. with cord fixed)
(ii) All T4 lesions
(iii) Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
(iv) Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement (v) Lesions of posterior commissure
(vi) Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
(vii) Transglottic cancers, i.e. tumours involving supraglottis and glottis across the ventricle, causing fixation of the vocal cord.
 

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page. No- 351.

questions.text: 55y old Uncontrolled Diabetes and Ca lung patient presents with a white corrugated plaque on the lateral border of the tongue that cannot be rubbed off. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Given scenario of an Immunocompromised man with White corrugated plaque that cannot be rubbed off is suggestive oral Hairy Leukoplakia. The causative organism is Epstein Barr Virus.

* Extra Edge: 

Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL) is a lesion frequently, although not exclusively, observed in patients infected by human immunodeficiency viruses (HIV). OHL is clinically characterized by bilateral, often elevated, white patches of the lateral borders and dorsum of the tongue. Histologically, there is profound acanthosis, sometimes with koilocytic changes, and a lack of a notable inflammatory infiltrate. The koilocytic changes are due to intense replication of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), while epithelial hyperplasia and acanthosis are likely to result from the combined action of the EBV-encoded proteins, latent membrane protein-1, and antiapoptotic BHRF1. How OHL is initiated and whether it develops after EBV reactivation from latency or superinfection remain unresolved; nevertheless, definitive diagnosis requires the demonstration of EBV replicating vegetatively in histological or cytological specimens. In patients with HIV infection, the development of OHL may herald severe HIV disease and the rapid onset of AIDS, but despite its title, OHL is not regarded as premalignant and is unlikely to give rise to oral squamous cell carcinoma.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No: 354, 733.

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Vocal nodules are bilateral, small, symmetric swellings located at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords — the point of maximal vibration.

  • They are commonly seen in teachers, singers, and other professional voice users due to chronic voice abuse or overuse.

  • The patient typically presents with hoarseness of voice and vocal fatigue.

  • On fiberoptic laryngoscopy, bilateral whitish nodules are seen on the free edge of the true vocal cords.

Differentiation:

  • Vocal cyst: Usually unilateral, smooth, and deeper within the cord substance.

  • Reinke’s edema: Diffuse, bilateral swelling of the entire vocal cord due to fluid accumulation (common in smokers).

  • Vocal polyp: Unilateral, pedunculated or sessile, caused by acute voice abuse or trauma.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following type of stridor will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is a viral infection—most commonly caused by parainfluenza virus type 1—that leads to inflammation and narrowing of the subglottic region of the larynx.

Because the obstruction is extrathoracic (above the vocal cords), the airflow is restricted during inspiration, producing a harsh, barking cough and inspiratory stridor.

Summary of stridor types:

  • Inspiratory stridor: Obstruction above the vocal cords (e.g., croup, laryngomalacia)

  • Expiratory stridor: Obstruction in the lower trachea or bronchi

  • Biphasic stridor: Fixed obstruction at or below the glottis (e.g., subglottic stenosis, tracheal compression)

Hence, croup typically presents with an inspiratory stridor.

choices.text: Patient will present with an inspiratory stridor
It is the most common congenital cause of stridor in children

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about laryngomalacia?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor in infants. It is due to floppy supraglottic structures that collapse during inspiration.

Key points:

  • Clinical features:

    • Inspiratory stridor — worsens when supine, crying, feeding, or agitated

    • Usually appears within the first 2 weeks of life

  • Natural course:

    • Most cases resolve spontaneously by 12–18 months as airway structures strengthen

  • Incorrect statement:

    • Stridor worsens in the supine position, it does not improve.

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Vocal nodules, also known as singer's nodes or screamer's nodes, are small, benign swellings that develop on the vocal cords.

They typically occur at the mid-membranous portion of the vocal cords, at the free edge, which is the area of maximum vibration and trauma during voice use.



Etiology: Vocal nodules develop due to vocal trauma or overuse, such as speaking loudly or for prolonged periods. They are common in professions like teachers, actors, vendors, and singers.

Symptoms:

Hoarseness of voice.
Vocal fatigue.
Pain in the neck with prolonged use of the voice.
Treatment involves:

Voice therapy: Educating the patient on proper voice techniques to reduce strain.
Surgery is considered only for patients who do not improve with voice therapy

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does a patient with Reinke's edema classically present with?
questions.solution:
Diplophonia is the hallmark symptom of Reinke's edema. It can also occur in other conditions such as vocal polyps and vocal cord cysts.

Dysphonia, though present in Reinke's edema, is not unique to this condition. Dysphonia refers to a difficulty in producing voice and is often synonymous with hoarseness, a sign of altered voice quality. It is a common symptom when the vocal cords are involved.

Reinke's space is a potential space beneath the epithelium of the vocal cords, located in the glottis. It contains minimal subepithelial connective tissue. Reinke's edema, or smoker's larynx, occurs when this space becomes edematous, often due to smoking.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngeal cancer stage T1b NO MO?
questions.solution:
In stage T1b N0 M0 laryngeal cancer, both vocal cords are involved, but they remain mobile.

The T1b stage specifically refers to tumors that affect both vocal cords but do not impair their mobility.

N0 means there is no regional lymph node involvement, and M0 indicates no distant metastasis.

This stage suggests an early laryngeal cancer with involvement of both vocal cords but without spread to lymph nodes or other parts of the body, and treatment is often focused on preserving voice function.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can cause laryngismus stridulus?
questions.solution:
Laryngismus stridulus can be defined as laryngeal spasm caused by the sudden contraction of laryngeal muscles due to a reduced level of calcium. It is likely to be caused by vitamin D deficiency.
Causes of vitamin D deficiency :
• Inadequate sunlight exposure.
• Poor dietary intake.
• Malabsorption disorders such as celiac disease.
• Liver or kidney disorders affecting vitamin D metabolism.
• Calcium Deficiency: Even with sufficient vitamin D, a diet low in calcium can lead to rickets.
• Phosphate Deficiency: Rarely, genetic disorders like hypophosphatemic rickets, which affect phosphate metabolism, can cause rickets.
Clinical features include bone pain and tenderness, delayed growth, skeletal deformities -bowed legs (genu varum) or knock knees (genu valgum), thickened wrists and ankles, and a protruding breastbone (pectus carinatum), dental problems muscle spasms, including those affecting the larynx.
Radiological features show cupping at metaphyses, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.
Ref: online source - https://www.indianpediatrics.net/epub122021/RECOMM-00382.pdf

questions.text: A 4 year old child presented with recurrent URTI and excessive day time sleepiness his parents also noticed child has been snoring during sleep. On evaluation he has hyponasal character of voice wit the following facial characteristics. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Adenoid hypertrophy is an obstructive condition due to enlarged adenoids. This can occur with or without an acute or chronic infection of the adenoids. The condition is more common in children than in adults; the adenoids naturally atrophy and regress during adolescence. Adenoid hypertrophy causes typical facies characterized by an elongated face with a dull expression, an open mouth, a hitched-up upper lip, prominent upper teeth causing crowding (malocclusion of teeth), a high arched hard palate (due to loss of tongue's molding action on the palate), and a pinched-in nose due to disuse atrophy of the alae nasi.
NOSE
bM
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery - 8th
Edition • Page no: 29, 75-77

questions.text: A 5 week-old boy presented with noisy breathing, since a few days after birth. On valuation Inspiratory stridor is heard. Laryngoscopy showed the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in children. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. The presentation is just after birth and subsides by 2 years. Stridor improves(decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy omega shaped epiglottis is seen.
Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition • Page no 2036

questions.text: A chronic smoker comes to your OPD and you diagnose him to have Erythroplakia. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution: The next best step in case of management of Erythroplakia is to stop smoking and do an excision biopsy. It is a premalignant oral lesion that presents as a bright red velvety patch commonly presents at the lower alveolar mucosa, gingivobuccal sulcus and floor of the mouth. The red colour is due to decreased keratinisation. It has higher malignant position than leukoplakia hence excision biopsy and follow up is neccesary. Ref- Bailey and Love 28th edition page 815

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with a mild cold. On examination, he is found to have adenoid facies. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
• Adenoid facies (long face, open mouth, nasal speech) usually results from chronic nasal obstruction due to enlarged adenoids.

  • Treatment of choice: Adenoidectomy, especially if there are:

    • Recurrent infections

    • Obstructive symptoms (nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, snoring)

    • Sleep disturbances

  • Coblation technique is preferred in modern practice:

    • Minimally invasive

    • Causes less bleeding and tissue damage compared to traditional curettage

Other options:

  • Breathing exercises with nasal decongestants: May provide temporary relief but do not reduce adenoid size; not definitive treatment.

  • Endoscopic microdebridement: More often used for sinus surgery; not standard for adenoid hypertrophy.

  • Adenoid curettage: Traditional method; effective but higher risk of bleeding and tissue trauma compared to coblation.



Reference :

P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery - 8th Edition - Page no 287, 288,507, 508

questions.text:
A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.



Which of the following stridor is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical situation points to laryngomalacia as the cause, as does the laryngoscopy imaging that reveals an omega-shaped epiglottis. Its the most common cause of stridor in infancy.
Laryngomalacia is characterized by supraglottic tissues that are excessively floppy and draw inward during inspiration, resulting in the distinctive inspiratory stridor. 

Worsening of stridor -  Screaming and eating/supine
Betterment of Stridor-  Prone position

Usually manifesting soon after birth, laryngomalacia usually goes away by the time a child is two years old.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat - PL Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page 333.

questions.text: A child is brought to the casualty with a history of dyspnea. His mother gives a history of foreign body aspiration. What is the first investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
• In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, the first investigation is usually a chest and neck X-ray:

    • Detects radio-opaque foreign bodies

    • Shows air trapping, atelectasis, or mediastinal shift if the object is radiolucent

    • Non-invasive, quick, and readily available, making it the initial screening tool

Other options:

  • Rigid endoscopy / Direct laryngoscopy: Diagnostic and therapeutic, but invasive; usually performed after imaging or if X-ray is inconclusive and clinical suspicion is high.

  • Flexible endoscopy: Useful for airway evaluation; less ideal for acute foreign body removal in children.



Reference:
Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Pages 2211-2212.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Laryngocele is an abnormal air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule that communicates with the laryngeal lumen.

  • It is classically seen in wind instrument players (like trumpet players) due to repeated raised intralaryngeal pressure.

  • Features:

    • Hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling.

    • Swelling increases in size on coughing / Valsalva maneuver.

    • Gurgling sound on compression due to air-filled sac.

Other options:

  • Thyroglossal cyst → midline swelling, moves with tongue protrusion and deglutition, not related to Valsalva.

  • Zenker’s diverticulum → pharyngoesophageal pouch; presents with regurgitation, halitosis, aspiration, but no neck swelling increasing on Valsalva.

  • Cystic hygroma → congenital lymphatic malformation, soft cystic swelling in posterior triangle, does not gurgle or change with Valsalva.


A trumpet player with swelling increasing on Valsalva + gurgling sound = Laryngocele.


Reference

PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition - Page nos 310-311, 345, 445, 447, 507

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. On examination, a pseudomembrane was noted over the tonsils which bleed on trying to remove and a bull-neck appearance of the neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child presents with classic signs of diphtheria, especially notable in unimmunized children. Key features include:

Clinical Clues Pointing to Diphtheria:

  • Fever, cough, and respiratory distress

  • Pseudomembrane over tonsils:

    • Greyish-white or dirty membrane

    • Firmly adherent and bleeds on removal (a hallmark feature)

  • Bull-neck appearance:

    • Due to massive cervical lymphadenopathy and soft tissue edema

  • Unimmunized status increases risk significantly

    Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  1. Infectious Mononucleosis:

    • Can cause tonsillar enlargement and exudate, but pseudomembrane is not typical.

    • Bleeding on removal is not a characteristic feature.

  2. Candidiasis:

    • White curd-like patches that are easily scraped off without bleeding.

    • Common in immunocompromised or infants.

  3. Tonsillitis:

    • May cause exudate and fever, but no pseudomembrane, and no bull-neck.


Reference:The diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head And Neck surgery 7th edition page no 294.

questions.text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The child presents with classic features of adenoid hypertrophy with otitis media with effusion (OME):

Key Features:

  • Recurrent URTIs + mouth breathing + high arched palate → suggest adenoid hypertrophy

  • Impaired hearing → due to OME (fluid in the middle ear)

  • High-arched palate is also a sign of chronic mouth breathing

    Management:

  • Adenoidectomy is done to relieve the nasal obstruction and mouth breathing caused by hypertrophied adenoids.

  • Grommet insertion (ventilation tubes) is done to manage the middle ear effusion and restore hearing.

Hence, Adenoidectomy + grommet insertion is the most appropriate treatment.

Other Options:

  • Adenoidectomy alone: Does not address middle ear fluid.

  • Myringotomy with grommet insertion alone: Middle ear problem may recur due to persistent adenoid hypertrophy.

  • Tonsillectomy: Indicated for chronic tonsillitis, not adenoids or OME.



Reference:PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head And Neck surgery 7th edition page no 70,491

questions.text: What is the purpose of the following instrument?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscope seen here has a curved blade and is used for direct laryngoscopy.
Most tracheal intubations are performed using a viewing device.
The most often used tool for this purpose has traditionally been the traditional laryngoscope. A set of interchangeable blades plus a handle with batteries and a light source make up the standard laryngoscope.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 481,521

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'cold' method of tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Microdebrider is a 'cold' method for tonsillectomy, while rest are considered 'hot' methods

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 489

questions.text: Identify the given instrument:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a Blom-Singer prosthesis, which, along with the Panje prosthesis, is a type of tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP).

Key Features of Tracheoesophageal Prosthesis:
Mechanism: The TEP includes a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. When the patient occludes the stoma, exhaled air is redirected through the TEP into the esophagus.
Phonation: This airflow induces vibrations in the upper esophageal sphincter, facilitating sound production for speech.
Voice Quality: TEP provides the most intelligible, fluent, and natural-sounding voice compared to other laryngeal speech methods.
